Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-511 Identification number inspection.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
An application for a certificate of title for a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor not previously titled in this state shall be accompanied by a certificate of identification number inspection obtained in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512 Application for title.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1): The application for a certificate of title shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1)(a): the signature of a person to be recorded on the certificate as owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1)(b): the name, bona fide residence and mailing address of the owner, or business address of the owner if the owner is a firm, association, or corporation;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1)(c): a description of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor, including the make, model, type of body, the model year as specified by the manufacturer, the number of cylinders, the identification number of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor, as applicable, and other information the division may require;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1)(d): other information required by the division to enable it to determine whether the owner is entitled to a certificate of title;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1)(e): a statement of one lien or encumbrance, if any, upon the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(1)(f): the names and addresses of all persons having any ownership interest in the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor and the nature of the ownership interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-512(2): An application for a certificate of title for a new vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor purchased from a dealer shall be accompanied by a statement by the dealer or a bill of sale showing any lien retained by the dealer.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-513 Examination of registration records and indices of stolen and recovered vehicles, vessels, and outboard motors.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division upon receiving application for any certificate of title shall first check the identification number shown in the application against the indices of registered vehicles, vessels, and outboard motors and against indices of stolen and recovered vehicles, vessels, and outboard motors.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514 Certificate of title -- Contents.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1): The division upon approving an application for a certificate of title shall issue a certificate of title.  The face of the certificate of title shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1)(a): the date issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1)(b): the name and address of the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1)(c): a description of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor titled, including the year, make, and identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1)(d): a statement of the owner's title and of one lien or encumbrance, if any, upon the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1)(e): any brand on the title; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(1)(f): an odometer statement, if applicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(2): The certificate of title shall bear the seal of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(3): The certificate of title shall contain adequate space for:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(3)(a): the assignment and warranty of title or interest by the owner;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(3)(b): the release of interest by a recorded lien holder; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(3)(c): the notation of one lien or encumbrance, if any, existing at the time of transfer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(4): The model year that is listed on the certificate of title of a replica vehicle shall be the model year that the body of the vehicle resembles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-514(5): The certificate of title of a replica vehicle shall indicate that the vehicle is a replica vehicle.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515 Delivery of certificate by division.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515(1): The division shall deliver the certificate of title to the owner if no lien or encumbrance is recorded on it.  The division shall deliver the certificate to the person holding the first lien or encumbrance as recorded on the certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515(2): The certificate of title shall be delivered:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515(2)(a): in person;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515(2)(b): through the United States mail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515(2)(c): electronically.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-515(3): If delivered through the United States mail, receipt of the certificate of title is presumed four days after the mail has been posted.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-516 Annual renewal of titles unnecessary -- Superseded certificates invalid.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-516(1): Certificates of title need not be renewed annually but shall remain valid until canceled by the division for cause or upon a transfer of any interest shown on the certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-516(2): 41-1a-518 A certificate of title is invalid when superseded by a duplicate certificate issued under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-517 Change of name -- New title.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-517(1): If the name of any person who has made application for or obtained a certificate of title is legally changed, the person shall surrender the certificate and file an application for a new certificate of title.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-517(2): The division upon receipt of the required fees shall issue a new certificate of title.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518 Duplicate titles.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(1)(a): If a certificate of title is lost, stolen, mutilated, or becomes illegible, the owner, legal representative, or successor in interest of the owner of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor for which the certificate was issued, as shown by the records of the division, shall immediately apply for and may obtain a duplicate upon furnishing information satisfactory to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(1)(b): A certificate of title issued under this section shall have printed or stamped in ink upon its face "duplicate".
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(1)(c): The duplicate certificate, when properly issued, supersedes and invalidates all other certificates previously issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(2): Part 12, Fee and Tax Requirements
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(2)(a): When the application for a duplicate certificate of title is accompanied by a proper release of interest from the owner or owners of record and a proper release of interest from the lienholder of record and the release is accompanied by a proper application to title the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor in the name of the new owner or owners, a duplicate certificate need not be made.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(2)(b): The division may issue a certificate of title in the name of the new owner or owners.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-518(2)(c): Part 12, Fee and Tax Requirements The duplicate title fees provided under


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-519 Dealer requirements for certificate of title or receipt of surrender of title.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-519(1): If a dealer delivers a new off-highway vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor to the purchaser, the dealer shall apply for issuance of a certificate of title or receipt of surrender of ownership documents, as appropriate, in the purchaser's name within 45 days of the date of sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-519(2): A dealer who purchases or takes in trade a used off-highway vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor on which a certificate of title has previously been issued is not required to apply for a certificate of title.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-520 Registration without issuing Utah title.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-520(1): If a person is relocating from another jurisdiction and establishing residence in this state, whether temporary or permanent, and that person has a vehicle registered and titled in another jurisdiction and is not able to surrender title to the vehicle being registered in the state because title is physically held by a lienholder, the division may register the vehicle without issuing a title.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-520(2): Upon satisfaction of the lien outstanding against the vehicle in the other jurisdiction, the registered owner shall within 10 days of receipt surrender the title from the other jurisdiction to the division and make application for a title.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-521 Release of prior certificate of title.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Every application for a certificate of title for a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor for which a certificate of title has previously been issued in this state or another jurisdiction shall be accompanied by the certificate of title.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-603 Issuance of new certificate of title -- Lienholder.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-603(1): Upon receipt of a title application the division shall file the application, and when satisfied as to the authenticity of the application, shall issue a new certificate of title in usual form, giving the name of the owner and a statement of one lien or encumbrance, if any, certified to the division as existing against the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-603(2): If a certificate of title has been issued, and the same lienholder as shown by the records of the division only grants additional funds to the same owner as shown by the records of the division, no further recording is required and no subsequent certificate of title need be applied for or issued, if the original certificate or valid duplicate has remained in possession of the lienholder and the lien has not been released and the certificate has not been delivered to the owner.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-607 Assignment by lienholder.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-607(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-607(1)(a): Any person holding a lien or encumbrance upon a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor, other than a lien dependent solely upon possession, may assign his title or interest in or to the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor to a person other than the owner without the consent of and without affecting the interest of the owner or the registration of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-607(1)(b): If assignment of the lien or encumbrance in any way modifies or affects the owner's repayment agreement, the lien or encumbrance holder shall give to the owner a written notice of the assignment.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-607(2): Upon request to the division and upon receipt of a certificate of title assigned by the holder of a lien or encumbrance shown on it and giving the name and address of the assignee, accompanied by the fee provided by law, the division shall issue a new certificate of title.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608 Release by lienholder to owner.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(1): A person holding a lien or encumbrance as shown upon a certificate of title upon a vehicle or vessel may release the lien or encumbrance or assign his interest to the owner without affecting the registration of the vehicle or vessel.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(2): The division shall issue a new certificate of title without a lien previously recorded upon receiving:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(2)(a): a certificate of title:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(2)(a)(i): upon which a lienholder has released or assigned his interest to the owner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(2)(a)(ii): not so endorsed but accompanied by a legal release from a lienholder of his interest in or to a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(2)(b): an application properly completed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-608(2)(c): the proper fee.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-609 Terminal rental adjustment clauses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-609(1): As used in this section, "terminal rental adjustment clause" means a provision of an agreement that permits or requires the rental price to be adjusted upward or downward by reference to the amount realized by the lessor under the agreement upon sale or other disposition of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-609(2): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a motor vehicle or trailer lease agreement that is subject to a terminal rental adjustment clause does not create a sale or security interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-609(3): Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act The provisions of this section do not affect:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-609(3)(a): the rights and obligations of a valid security interest under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-609(3)(b): Title 59, Chapter 12, Sales and Use Tax Act the calculation of sales and use tax payable under


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701 Transfer by owner -- Removal of plates.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(1)(a): If the owner of a registered vehicle transfers the title or interest to the vehicle the registration of the vehicle expires.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(1)(b): Unless an owner has included the transfer of a license plate as part of a sale, trade, or ownership release of a vehicle, the owner shall remove the license plates from the transferred vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(2)(a): If an owner does not transfer a license plate to a person as part of a sale, trade, or ownership release of a vehicle, within 20 days from the date of transfer the owner shall forward the plates to the division to be destroyed or may have the plates assigned to another vehicle, subject to the rules of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(2)(b): If an owner transfers a license plate as part of a sale, trade, or ownership release of a vehicle, the new registered owner of the transferred vehicle shall apply to the division to have the plates assigned to the new registered owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-701(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-702(1): 41-1a-705

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-702(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-702(2)(a): If a title certificate reflects the names of two or more people as co-owners in the alternative by use of the word "or" or "and/or," each co-owner is considered to have granted the other co-owners the absolute right to endorse and deliver title and to dispose of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-702(2)(b): If the title certificate reflects the names of two or more people as co-owners in the conjunctive by use of the word "and," or the title does not reflect any alternative or conjunctive word, the endorsement of each co-owner is required to transfer title to the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-706(1)(c): proper application for registration; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-706(1)(d): required fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-706(2): when satisfied as to the genuineness and regularity of the transfer and the right of the transferee to a certificate of title.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-708 Owner not liable for negligent operation after transfer.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The owner of a vehicle or vessel who has made a bona fide sale or transfer of his title or interest and who has delivered to the purchaser or transferee possession of the vehicle or vessel, the certificate of registration, and the properly endorsed certificate of title to the vehicle or vessel is not liable for any damages thereafter resulting from negligent operation of the vehicle or vessel by another.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-709 Dealer transfer of used off-highway vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Upon the resale or subsequent transfer by a dealer of a used off-highway vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor, the dealer shall endorse the certificate of title and forward it, accompanied by the transferee's application for a certificate of title, or if desired by the purchaser, and as applicable, a receipt of surrender of ownership documents, to the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-710 Certificate of origin required for acquisition or resale of vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-710(1): A dealer may not acquire a new  vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor without obtaining a manufacturer's or importer's certificate of origin.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-710(2): A manufacturer, importer, dealer, or other person may not sell or otherwise dispose of a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor for purposes of resale without delivering a manufacturer's or importer's certificate of origin to the purchaser or the new owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-710(3): The division may prescribe uniform standards for the size and content of certificates of origin.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-711 Compliance of foreign motor vehicle required prior to sale -- Penalty.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-711(1): 41-1a-225 A person may not knowingly sell or offer for sale in this state any vehicle referred to in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-711(1)(a): legal entry of the vehicle into the United States from the United States Customs Service; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-711(1)(b): compliance with the United States Environmental Protection Agency and the United States Department of Transportation requirements applicable to the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-711(2): It is a class A misdemeanor to violate this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712 Foreign vehicle disclosure requirements -- Penalties -- Civil damages.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1): A person may not knowingly sell or offer for sale in this state any vehicle that was initially delivered for disposition or sale in a country other than the United States of America unless, prior to the sale, the person provides written notice to the purchaser on a separate form furnished by the Motor Vehicle Enforcement Division:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(a): that indicates:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(a)(i): that the vehicle was initially delivered for disposition or sale in a country outside of the United States as indicated on the Manufacturer's Statement of Origin or similar ownership document; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(a)(ii): the country where the vehicle was initially delivered for the disposition or sale; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(b): that contains language substantially similar to each of the following statements:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(b)(i): "the odometer for this vehicle may have been converted to miles";
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(b)(ii): "this vehicle meets U.S. Department of Transportation safety standards"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(1)(b)(iii): "this vehicle may have manufacturer warranty exclusions if sold or offered for sale in this country."
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(2): A person who violates this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(3)(a): In addition to any other penalties, a purchaser may bring a civil action to recover damages resulting from a seller's failure to provide notice as required under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-712(3)(b): The amount of damages that may be recovered in a civil action are the actual damages or $1,500, whichever is greater.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801 Altered or changed identification number -- State assigned identification number.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(1): The owner of a vehicle required to be registered  under this chapter, the identification number of which has been altered, removed, defaced, or has not been placed on it shall make application in the form prescribed by the division for a state assigned identification number.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(2): The owner shall furnish  information that will satisfy the division that he is the owner of the vehicle and furnish information to identify the vehicle with the registration of the vehicle for the current year, at which time the division shall assign a  state identification number for the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(3): A record of state assigned numbers shall be maintained by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(4): The state assigned identification number is the identification number of the vehicle when:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(4)(a): the owner  has stamped the state assigned identification number upon the vehicle as directed by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(4)(b): a qualified identification number inspector has inspected and found the state assigned identification number stamped upon the vehicle as directed;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(4)(c): the owner has provided the division with a certificate of inspection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-801(4)(d): the owner has submitted an application for a certificate of title.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803 Identification numbers -- Assigning numbers -- Requirement for sale.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(1)(a): If a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor has a permanent manufacturer's identification number, the number shall be used as the vehicle's, vessel's, or outboard motor's  identification number.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(1)(b): If it has no permanent manufacturer's identification number, the division shall assign an identification number to it.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(1)(c): An identification number assigned by the division shall be permanently affixed or imprinted on the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor as directed by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(2): A person may not sell or offer for sale in this state a new vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor without an identification number.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(3)(a): Each permanent manufacturer's identification number for a vehicle shall be clearly marked in an accessible place on a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(3)(b)(i): Each permanent manufacturer's identification number for a vessel shall be clearly marked in an accessible place on the starboard outboard side of the transom or to the starboard outboard side of the hull.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(3)(b)(ii): If the permanent manufacturer's identification number is displayed in a location other than on or near the starboard outboard side of the transom, the manufacturer shall notify the division of its location.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(4): A person may not destroy, remove, alter, or cover an identification number.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-803(5): (4) A violation of this section is an infraction, except that Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-804 Garagemen, repair shops, and service stations -- Duty to report number violations.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person owning, conducting, managing, or operating a service station, marina, marine dealership, public garage, paint shop, or repair shop for vehicles, vessels, or outboard motors shall immediately notify the local peace officers of any vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor that has any identification number that has apparently been altered, obliterated, or removed.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-901 Odometer required.
--------------------------------------------------
Each motor vehicle required to be registered under this chapter shall be equipped with a properly functioning odometer.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902 Odometer disclosure statement -- Contents -- Receipt -- Exceptions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(1): Each motor vehicle certificate of title, at the time it is issued to the transferee, shall contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(1)(a): the mileage disclosed by the transferor when ownership of the motor vehicle was transferred; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(1)(b): a space for the information required to be disclosed under this section at the time of future transfer of ownership.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2): At the time of any sale or transfer of a motor vehicle, the transferor shall furnish to the transferee a written odometer disclosure statement in a form prescribed by the division. This statement shall be signed and certified as to its truthfulness by the transferor, stating:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(a): the date of transfer;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(b): the transferor's name and address;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(c): the transferee's name and address;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(d): the identity of the motor vehicle, including its make, model, year, body type, and identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(e): the odometer reading at the time of transfer, not including tenths of miles or tenths of kilometers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(f)(i): that to the best of the transferor's knowledge, the odometer reading reflects the amount of miles or kilometers the motor vehicle has actually been driven;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(f)(ii): that the odometer reading reflects the amount of miles or kilometers in excess of the designed mechanical odometer limit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(f)(iii): that the odometer reading is not the actual amount of miles or kilometers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(2)(g): a warning to alert the transferee if a discrepancy exists between the odometer reading and the actual mileage.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(3): (2); 41-3-301
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(3)(a): (2) Each transferee of a motor vehicle shall acknowledge receipt of the odometer disclosure statement required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(3)(b): 41-3-301 A dealer who is required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(4): Notwithstanding the requirements of this section, the odometer mileage need not be disclosed by a transferor of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(4)(a): a single motor vehicle having a manufacturer specified gross laden weight rating of more than 16,000 pounds, or a motor vehicle registered in this state for a gross laden weight of 18,000 pounds or more;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(4)(b): a motor vehicle that is 20 years old or older;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(4)(c): a motor vehicle sold directly by the manufacturer to any agency of the United States in conformity with contractual specifications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(4)(d): a new motor vehicle prior to its first transfer for purposes other than resale.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(5): If the motor vehicle has not been titled or if the certificate of title does not contain a space for the information required, the written disclosure shall be executed as a separate document.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-902(6): A person may not sign an odometer disclosure statement as both the transferor and the transferee in the same transaction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-903(1)(a): Before executing any transfer of ownership document, each lessor of a leased motor vehicle shall notify the lessee in writing that the lessee is required to provide a written disclosure to the lessor regarding the mileage.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-903(1)(b): This notice shall state that failure to complete or providing false information may result in fines, imprisonment, or both.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-903(2): 41-1a-902
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-903(2)(a): In connection with the transfer of ownership of the leased motor vehicle, the lessee shall furnish to the lessor a written statement regarding the mileage of the motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-903(2)(b): 41-1a-902 This statement must be signed by the lessee and shall contain all of the information required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-903(2)(c): The statement shall be signed and certified as to its truthfulness by the lessee.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-906 Repair or replacement of odometer -- Notice affixed to motor vehicle.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-906(2): Where the odometer is incapable of registering the same mileage as before the repair or replacement, the odometer shall be adjusted to zero and a notice in writing shall be affixed by the owner to the left door frame of the motor vehicle specifying the mileage prior to repair or replacement of the odometer and the date it was repaired or replaced.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(1): "Certified vehicle inspector" means a person employed by the Motor Vehicle Enforcement Division as qualified through experience, training, or both to identify and analyze damage to vehicles with either unibody or conventional frames.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(2): "Major component part" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(2)(a): the front body component of a motor vehicle consisting of the structure forward of the firewall;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(2)(b): the passenger body component of a motor vehicle including the firewall, roof, and extending to and including the rear-most seating;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(2)(c): the rear body component of a motor vehicle consisting of the main cross member directly behind the rear-most seating excluding any auxiliary seating and structural body assembly rear of the cross members; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(2)(d): the frame of a motor vehicle consisting of the structural member that supports the auto body.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(3)(a): "Major damage" means damage to a major component part of the motor vehicle requiring 10 or more hours to repair or replace, as determined by a collision estimating guide recognized by the Motor Vehicle Enforcement Division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(3)(b): (3)(a) For purposes of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(4): "Nonrepairable certificate" means a certificate of ownership issued for a nonrepairable vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5): "Nonrepairable vehicle" means a vehicle of a type otherwise subject to registration that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(a): has no resale value except as a source of parts or scrap metal or that the owner irreversibly designates as a source of parts or scrap metal or for destruction;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(b)(i): has little or no resale value other than its worth as a source of a vehicle identification number that could be used illegally; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(b)(ii)(A): has been substantially stripped as a result of theft; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(b)(ii)(B): is missing all of the bolt-on sheet metal body panels, all of the doors and hatches, substantially all of the interior components, and substantially all of the grill and light assemblies; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(c): is a substantially burned vehicle that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(c)(i): has burned to the extent that there are no more usable or repairable body or interior components, tires and wheels, or drive train components; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(5)(c)(ii): the owner irreversibly designates for destruction or as having little or no resale value other than its worth as a source of scrap metal or as a source of a vehicle identification number that could be used illegally.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(6): "Owner" means the person who has the legal right to possession of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(7)(a): "Salvage certificate" means a certificate of ownership issued for a salvage vehicle before a new certificate of title is issued for the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(7)(b): A salvage certificate is not valid for registration purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(8): "Salvage vehicle" means any vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(8)(a): damaged by collision, flood, or other occurrence to the extent that the cost of repairing the vehicle for safe operation exceeds its fair market value; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1001(8)(b): that has been declared a salvage vehicle by an insurer or other state or jurisdiction, but is not precluded from further registration and titling.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1006 Vehicle damaged out-of-state -- Division to make a record.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1006(1): If a vehicle that is titled in this state is damaged in another state or jurisdiction but would require a salvage certificate in this state and the vehicle is not returned to the state, the owner of the vehicle must notify the purchaser and the division that if the vehicle is subsequently titled in Utah the certificate of title will be branded as a salvage vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1006(2): The division shall make a record of the damage.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1102 Storage -- Establishing ownership.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1102(1): The division may store a seized vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor in a public or private garage, state impound lot, or other approved storage facility until the vehicle's, vessel's, or outboard motor's registration has been properly completed and the appropriate fees have been paid or until the ownership of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor is established to the satisfaction of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1102(2): If the identification number has been defaced, altered, or obliterated, the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor may not be released until the identification number has been replaced or until a new number assigned by the division has been provided and has been affixed to the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105 Records to be kept by public garage, impound lot, or impound yard.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(1)(a): Each person engaged in the business of operating a public garage, impound lot, or impound yard shall keep a record of every vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor stored in it for compensation for a period longer than 12 hours.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(1)(b): The record shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(1)(b)(i): the name and address of the person storing  the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(1)(b)(ii): a brief description of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor, including the name or make, identification number, and  license number shown by the  license plates; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(1)(b)(iii): the mileage shown on the vehicle's odometer both upon arrival at and upon its release from the public garage, impound lot, or impound yard, if the vehicle is equipped with an odometer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1105(2): (1) Every record kept under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1106 Storage of vehicles, vessels, and outboard motors -- Reports required.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If any vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor has been stored in a public garage, state impound lot, or other storage facility for 10 days and the owner is unknown to the proprietor, on the 11th day of storage the proprietor shall report the presence of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor to the law enforcement agency in the city or county where the garage, lot, or facility is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1202 Refused or rejected application -- Refunds.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
If an application to the  division is accompanied by any fees required by law and the application is refused or rejected, the fees shall be returned immediately to the applicant.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1203 Application for refund.
--------------------------------------------------------
If the division through error collects any fee not required to be paid, the fee shall be refunded to the person paying the fee upon written application for a refund made within six months after date of the payment.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1207 Reduced fees for portion of year.
------------------------------------------------------------------
If a motor vehicle exceeding 12,000 pounds gross laden weight is registered for less than a 12-month registration period, the registration fees are:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1207(1): for not more than three months, 30% of the regular registration fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1207(2): for in excess of three months but not more than six months, 60% of the regular registration fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1207(3): for in excess of six months and not more than nine months, 90% of the regular registration fee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1207(4): for anything in excess of nine months but not more than 12 months, the entire registration fee.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1208 Fees for duplicate certificates of registration.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A duplicate certificate of registration may be issued upon application and payment of $4 to the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1209 Exemptions from registration fees.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1209(1): A fee may not be charged for the registration of ambulances, law enforcement vehicles, fire engines, and passenger cars and trucks owned and used by the United States government or by the state of Utah or any of its political subdivisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1209(2): A fee may not be charged municipal corporations for the issuance of any certificate of title or registration or a duplicate certificate of title or registration.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1210 Fees for original and duplicate certificates of title.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A fee of $6 shall be paid to the division for the issuance of each original and duplicate certificate of title for a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301 Unpaid fees and penalty -- Lien -- Seizure and sale.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301(1)(a): Every registration fee and penalty not paid by  the due date is a lien upon all:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301(1)(a)(i): the unexempt personal property of the owner or operator of the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301(1)(a)(ii): interest or equity of the owner or operator in all personal property, including vehicles, vessels, or outboard motors used by the owner or operator in the conduct or operation of his business.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301(1)(b): The properties and vehicles, vessels, or outboard motors may be held under warrant, issued by the commission, and sold in accordance with the law applicable to personal property taxes.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1301(2): Delinquency is a ground for the issuance of a writ of attachment against the owner or operator.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1302 Infraction.
--------------------------------------------
A violation of any provision of this chapter is an infraction, unless otherwise provided.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1304 Operating motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer in excess of registered gross laden weight -- Infraction.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is an infraction for a person to operate, or cause to be operated, a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, or combination of them the gross laden weight of which is in excess of the gross laden weight for which the motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, or combination of vehicles is registered.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305 License plate and registration card violations -- Class C misdemeanor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a class C misdemeanor:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(1): to break, injure, interfere with, or remove from any vehicle any seal, lock, or device on it for holding or displaying any license plate or registration card attached for denoting registration and identity of the vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(2): to remove from any registered vehicle the license plate or registration card issued or attached to it for its registration;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(3): to place or display any license plate or registration card upon any other vehicle than the one for which it was issued by the  division;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(4): to use or permit the use or display of any license plate, registration card, or permit upon or in the operation of any vehicle other than that for which it was issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(5): to operate upon any highway of this state any vehicle required by law to be registered without having the license plate or plates securely attached, except that the registration card issued by the division to all trailers and semitrailers shall be carried in the towing vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(6): for any weighmaster to knowingly make any false entry in his record of weights of vehicles subject to registration or to knowingly report to the commission or division any false information regarding the weights;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(7): for any inspector, officer, agent, employee, or other person performing any of the functions required  for the registration or operation of vehicles subject to registration, to do, permit, cause, connive at, or permit to be done any act with the intent, or knowledge that the probable effect of the act would be to injure any person, deprive him of his property, or to injure or defraud the state with respect to its revenues relating to title or registration of vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(8): for any person to combine or conspire with another to do, attempt to do, or cause or allow any of the acts in this chapter classified as a misdemeanor;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(9): to operate any motor vehicle with a camper mounted on it upon any highway without displaying a current decal in clear sight upon the rear of the camper, issued by the county assessor of the county in which the camper has situs for taxation;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(10): to manufacture, use, display, or sell any facsimile or reproduction of any license plate issued by the  division or any article that would appear to be a substitute for a license plate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(11): to fail to return to the  division any registration card, license plate or plates, decal, permit, or title that has been canceled, suspended, voided, or revoked.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a class C misdemeanor:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(1): to break, injure, interfere with, or remove from any vehicle any seal, lock, or device on it for holding or displaying any license plate or registration card attached for denoting registration and identity of the vehicle;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1305(11): to fail to return to the division any registration card, license plate or plates, registration decal, permit, or title that has been canceled, suspended, voided, or revoked.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1307 Operation of motor vehicles, trailers, or semitrailers without payment of fees -- Infraction.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1307(1): It is an infraction for a person to operate a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer upon the highways without having paid the title and registration or transfer fees and taxes required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1307(2): In addition to any other penalty, the owner of a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer operated in violation of this section shall pay a penalty equal to title and registration fees in addition to any other fee required under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1307(3): A court may require proof of proper vehicle registration as part of any sentence imposed under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1309 Boarding with intent to commit injury to motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer -- Class C misdemeanor.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a class C misdemeanor for a person with intent to commit any criminal mischief, injury, or other crime to:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1309(1): climb into or upon a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, whether it is in motion or at rest;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1309(2): attempt to manipulate any of the levers, starting mechanism, brakes, or other mechanism or device of a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer while the same is at rest and unattended; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1309(3): set in motion any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer while the same is at rest and unattended.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1313 Third degree felony to possess motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or parts without identification number -- Presumption of knowledge.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1313(1): It is a third degree felony for a person to have in his possession any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, or any part or parts of a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer, from which any identification number has been removed, defaced, destroyed, obliterated, or so covered as to be concealed, or where the identification number has been altered or changed in any manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1313(2): A person having possession of any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer or part of them under this section is presumed prima facie to have knowledge of this condition.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315 Third degree felony -- False evidences of title and registration.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a third degree felony for a person with respect to a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer to:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(1): fraudulently use a false or fictitious name in an application for registration, a certificate of title, or for a duplicate certificate of title;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(2): knowingly make a false statement or knowingly conceal a material fact in an application under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(3): otherwise commit a fraud in an application under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(4): alter with fraudulent intent a certificate of title, registration card, license plate, or permit issued by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(5): forge or counterfeit a document or license plate purporting to have been issued by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(6): alter, falsify, or forge an assignment upon a certificate of title;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(7): hold or use a document or license plate under this chapter knowing it has been altered, forged, or falsified; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1315(8): file an application for a certificate of title providing false lien information, when the person named on the application as lienholder does not hold a valid security interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1316 Receiving or transferring stolen motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a second degree felony for a person:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1316(1): with intent to procure or pass title to a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer that he knows or has reason to believe has been stolen or unlawfully taken to receive or transfer possession of the motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer from or to another; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1316(2): to have in his possession any motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer that he knows or has reason to believe has been stolen or unlawfully taken if he is not a peace officer engaged at the time in the performance of his duty.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1317 Selling or buying without identification numbers -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a second degree felony for a person to knowingly buy, receive, dispose of, sell, offer for sale, or have in his possession any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or engine removed from a motor vehicle, from which the identification number has been removed, defaced, covered, altered, or destroyed for the purpose of concealing or misrepresenting the identity of the motor vehicle or engine.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318 Second degree felony -- Fraudulent alteration of identification number.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318(1): It is a second degree felony for a person  with fraudulent intent to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318(1)(a): deface, destroy, or alter the  identification number or state assigned identification number of a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318(1)(b): place or stamp, without authority by the division, something other than the original identification or state assigned identification number upon a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318(1)(c): sell or offer for sale a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer bearing an altered or defaced identification or state  assigned identification number other than the original or the state assigned identification number.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318(2): This section does not prevent any manufacturer, importer, or any agent, other than a dealer, from placing or stamping in the ordinary course of business numbers on motor vehicles, trailers, or semitrailers registered under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1318(3): This section does not prohibit the restoration by an owner of an original identification number when the restoration is made under permit issued by the division.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1319 Third degree felony -- Odometer violation.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
It is a third degree felony for a person, with intent to defraud, to:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1319(1): disconnect, turn back, replace, or reset or cause to be disconnected, turned back, replaced, or reset, the odometer of any motor vehicle with the intent to reduce the true number of miles or kilometers indicated on it;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1319(2): 41-1a-902 knowingly sell, transfer, or exchange, or cause to be sold, transferred, or exchanged without the disclosure required by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1501 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Motor Vehicle Event Data Recorder Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(a): "Event data" means records of one or more of the following categories of information regarding a motor vehicle that are captured by an event data recorder:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(a)(i): whether the vehicle's air bag deployed;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(a)(ii): vehicle speed;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(a)(iii): vehicle steering performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(a)(iv): vehicle brake performance or use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(a)(v): vehicle seatbelt status or use.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(1)(b): "Event data" does not include audio and video data.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(2): "Event data recorder" has the same meaning as defined in 49 C.F.R. Sec. 563.5 as in effect on May 14, 2013.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(3)(a): "Owner" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(3)(a)(i): a person having all the incidents of ownership of a motor vehicle, including legal title to the motor vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(3)(a)(ii): a person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle as the purchaser under a security agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(3)(a)(iii): a person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle as a lessee under a written lease agreement if the lease agreement is intended to last for more than three months at its inception.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1502(3)(b): "Owner" does not include a lienholder unless the lienholder gains possession of the motor vehicle because the person entitled to possession of a motor vehicle as the purchaser under a security agreement defaults on the loan.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503 Event data recorders -- Retrieval or disclosure of event data.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(1): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(1)(a): (2) Event data that is recorded on an event data recorder:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(1)(a)(i): is private;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(1)(a)(ii): is the personal information of the motor vehicle's owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(1)(a)(iii): (2) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(1)(b): If a motor vehicle is owned by more than one person, only one owner is required to consent to the retrieval or use of the data from a motor vehicle event data recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2): Event data that is recorded on an event data recorder may be retrieved, obtained, or used by a person who is not the owner of the motor vehicle in the following circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(a): the owner of the motor vehicle or the owner's agent has consented to the retrieval of the data relating to an accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(b): the data is retrieved by a motor vehicle dealer, motor vehicle manufacturer, or by an automotive technician to diagnose, service, or repair the motor vehicle at the request of the owner or the owner's agent;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(c): the data is subject to discovery in a criminal prosecution or pursuant to the rules of civil procedure in a claim arising out of a motor vehicle accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(d): a court or administrative agency having jurisdiction orders the data to be retrieved;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(e): a peace officer retrieves the data pursuant to a court order as part of an investigation of a suspected violation of a law that has caused, or contributed to the cause of, an accident resulting in damage of property or injury to a person;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(f): to facilitate or determine the need for emergency medical care for the driver or passenger of a motor vehicle that is involved in a motor vehicle crash or other emergency, including the retrieval of data from a company that provides subscription services to the owner of a motor vehicle for in-vehicle safety and security communications; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(2)(g): for purposes of improving motor vehicle safety, security, or traffic management, including medical research on the human body's reaction to motor vehicle crashes, as long as the identity of the owner, passenger, or human driver is not disclosed in connection with the retrieved data.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(3): (4); (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(4): A person may release event data that is recorded on an event data recorder in the following circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(4)(a): the owner of the motor vehicle or the owner's agent has consented to the release of the data;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(4)(b): the data is subject to discovery in a criminal prosecution or pursuant to the rules of civil procedure in a claim arising out of a motor vehicle accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(4)(c): the data is released pursuant to a court order as part of an investigation of a suspected violation of a law that has caused, or contributed to the cause of, an accident resulting in damage of property or injury to a person; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(4)(d): if the identity of the owner or driver is not disclosed in connection with the retrieved data, the data is released for purposes of improving motor vehicle safety, security, or traffic management, including medical research on the human body's reaction to a motor vehicle crash.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(5)(a): If a motor vehicle is equipped with an event data recorder that is capable of recording or transmitting event data and that capability is part of a subscription service, the fact that the event data may be recorded or transmitted shall be disclosed in the subscription service agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1503(5)(b): (5)(a) Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, event data from an event data recorder may be retrieved, obtained, and used by a subscription service provider for subscription services meeting the requirement of Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1504 Effect of ownership transfer on ownership of data.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1504(1): Event data on a motor vehicle event data recorder does not become the property of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1504(1)(a): an insurer solely because the insurer succeeds in ownership of a motor vehicle as a result of an accident; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1504(1)(b): a subsequent purchaser solely because the subsequent purchaser becomes the new owner of the motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1504(2): An insurer or lessor of a motor vehicle may not require an owner to consent to the retrieval or use of the data on a motor vehicle event data recorder as a condition of providing the policy or lease.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(1): "Applicant" means a registered owner who submits an application to obtain or renew a sponsored special group license plate in accordance with this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a): "Charitable purpose" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(i): relief of the poor, the distressed, or the underprivileged;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(ii): advancement of religion;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(iii): advancement of education or science;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(vi): reducing neighborhood tensions;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(vii): eliminating prejudice and discrimination;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(viii): defending human rights and civil rights secured by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(a)(ix): combating community deterioration and juvenile delinquency.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(2)(b): "Charitable purpose" does not include providing, encouraging, or paying for the costs of obtaining an abortion.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(3): "Collegiate special group license plate" means a sponsored special group license plate issued to a contributor to an institution.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(15)(a): "State agency support special group license plate" means:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(15)(a)(ii): an existing special group license plate issued for a special interest vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1601(15)(b): "State agency support special group license plate" includes a cancer support license plate created by an act of the Legislature before December 31, 2022.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602 Sponsored special group license plate program.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602(1): The division shall establish and administer a sponsored special group license plate program as described in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602(2): The division shall issue to an applicant who satisfies the requirements of this part one of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602(2)(a): a collegiate special group license plate;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602(2)(b): a private nonprofit special group license plate;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602(2)(c): a state agency support special group license plate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1602(2)(d): a state agency recognition special group license plate.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1605 Collegiate special group license plates.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1605(1): A sponsoring organization that is an institution shall only use funds received through the sponsored special group license plate program for the institution's academic scholarships.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1605(2): The state auditor may audit each institution to verify that the money an institution collects from contributors is used only for academic scholarships.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1606 Private nonprofit special group license plates.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1606(1): 41-1a-1603 A sponsoring organization that is a private nonprofit organization shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1606(1)(a): 41-1a-1603 only use funds received through the sponsored special group license plate program for the charitable purpose described in the private nonprofit organization's application submitted to the division under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1606(1)(b): may not use funds received through the sponsored special group license plate program to pay the private nonprofit organization's employee salaries or benefits, administrative costs, or fundraising expenses.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1606(2): 41-1a-1604 A private nonprofit organization may collect a contributor's personal information for the purposes of future fundraising and any required reporting, if the private nonprofit organization requires a verification form described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1606(3): The state auditor may audit each private nonprofit organization to verify that the money the private nonprofit organization collects from contributors is used for the private nonprofit organization's charitable purpose in accordance with this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1607 State agency special group license plates.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
A sponsoring organization that is a state agency:Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1607(1): shall only use funds received through the sponsored special group license plate program for the implementation or administration of the state agency's designated program; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-1a-1607(2): may not direct funds received through the sponsored special group license plate program to a nongovernmental entity.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated - Title 41 - Chapter 3 - Motor Vehicle Business Regulation Act
**********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the Motor Vehicle Business Regulation Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(1): "Administrator" means the motor vehicle enforcement administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(2): "Agent" means a person other than a holder of any dealer's or salesperson's license issued under this chapter, who for salary, commission, or compensation of any kind, negotiates in any way for the sale, purchase, order, or exchange of three or more motor vehicles for any other person in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(3): "Auction" means a dealer engaged in the business of auctioning motor vehicles, either owned or consigned, to the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(4): (4)(a) "Authorized service center" means an entity that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(4)(a): is in the business of repairing exclusively the motor vehicles of the same line-make as the motor vehicles a single direct-sale manufacturer manufactures;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(4)(b): (4)(a) the direct-sale manufacturer described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(4)(c): conducts business primarily from an enclosed commercial repair facility that is permanently located in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(5): 41-3-106 "Board" means the advisory board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(6): "Body shop" means a person engaged in rebuilding, restoring, repairing, or painting the body of motor vehicles for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(7): "Commission" means the State Tax Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(8): Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act "Crusher" means a person who crushes or shreds motor vehicles subject to registration under
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(9)(a): "Dealer" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(9)(a)(i): whose business in whole or in part involves selling new, used, or new and used motor vehicles or off-highway vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(9)(a)(ii): who sells, displays for sale, or offers for sale or exchange three or more new or used motor vehicles or off-highway vehicles in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(9)(b): "Dealer" includes a representative or consignee of any dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10): "Direct-sale manufacturer" means a person:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(a): that is both a manufacturer and a dealer;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(b): that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(b)(i): an electric vehicle manufacturer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(b)(ii): a low-volume manufacturer;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(c): that is not a franchise holder;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(d): that is domiciled in the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(10)(e): whose chief officers direct, control, and coordinate the person's activities as a direct-sale manufacturer from a physical location in the United States.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(11): "Direct-sale manufacturer salesperson" means an individual who for a salary, commission, or compensation of any kind, is employed either directly, indirectly, regularly, or occasionally by a direct-sale manufacturer to sell, purchase, or exchange or to negotiate for the sale, purchase, or exchange of a motor vehicle manufactured by the direct-sale manufacturer who employs the individual.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(12): Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(12)(a): Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act "Dismantler" means a person engaged in the business of dismantling motor vehicles subject to registration under
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(12)(b): "Dismantler" includes a person who dismantles three or more motor vehicles in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(13): "Distributor" means a person who has a franchise from a manufacturer of motor vehicles to distribute motor vehicles within this state and who in whole or in part sells or distributes new motor vehicles to dealers or who maintains distributor representatives.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(14): "Distributor branch" means a branch office similarly maintained by a distributor for the same purposes a factory branch is maintained.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(15): "Distributor representative" means a person and each officer and employee of the person engaged as a representative of a distributor or distributor branch of motor vehicles to make or promote the sale of the distributor or the distributor branch's motor vehicles, or for supervising or contacting dealers or prospective dealers of the distributor or the distributor branch.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(16): 41-3-104 "Division" means the Motor Vehicle Enforcement Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(17): "Electric vehicle manufacturer" means a person that, in this state, sells, displays for sale, or offers for sale or exchange only new motor vehicles of the person's own line-make that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(17)(a): exclusively propelled through the use of electricity, a hydrogen fuel cell, or another non-fossil fuel source;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(17)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(17)(b)(i): passenger vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating of 14,000 pounds or less; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(17)(b)(ii): trucks with a gross vehicle weight rating of 14,000 pounds or less; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(17)(c): manufactured by the person.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(18): "Factory branch" means a branch office maintained by a person who manufactures or assembles motor vehicles for sale to distributors, motor vehicle dealers, or who directs or supervises the factory branch's representatives.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(19): "Factory representative" means a person and each officer and employee of the person engaged as a representative of a manufacturer of motor vehicles or by a factory branch to make or promote the sale of the manufacturer's or factory branch's motor vehicles, or for supervising or contacting the dealers or prospective dealers of the manufacturer or the factory branch.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(20): "Fleet transaction" means a licensee's sale of one or more motor vehicles to a manufacturer-approved current fleet customer under the manufacturer's fleet program.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(21)(b): (21)(a); Title 13, Chapter 14, New Automobile Franchise Act; Title 13, Chapter 35, Powersport Vehicle Franchise Act "Franchise" includes a contract or agreement described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(23): "Low-volume manufacturer" means a manufacturer who:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(23)(a): in this state, sells, displays for sale, or offers for sale or exchange only new motor vehicles of the person's own line make that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(23)(a)(i):

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(23)(a)(ii): manufactured by the person; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(23)(b): constructs no more than 325 new motor vehicles in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(24): "Line-make" means motor vehicles that are offered for sale, lease, or distribution under a common name, trademark, service mark, or brand name of the manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(25): "Manufacturer" means a person engaged in the business of constructing or assembling new motor vehicles, ownership of which is customarily transferred by a manufacturer's statement or certificate of origin, or a person who constructs three or more new motor vehicles in any 12-month period.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-102(26): (26)(a); (b) "Material owner" means a person who possesses, directly or indirectly, the power to direct, or cause the direction of, the management, policies, or activities of another person:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103 Exceptions to "dealer" definition -- Dealer licensed in other state -- Direct-sale manufacturer -- Direct-sale manufacturer salesperson.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Under this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(1): Title 7, Chapter 24, Title Lending Registration Act; Title 7, Chapter 23, Check Cashing and Deferred Deposit Lending Registration Act
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(1)(a): Title 7, Chapter 24, Title Lending Registration Act; Title 7, Chapter 23, Check Cashing and Deferred Deposit Lending Registration Act An insurance company, bank, finance company, company registered as a title lender under
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(1)(b): A person who sells or exchanges only those motor vehicles that the person has owned for over 12 months is not considered a dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(2)(a): A person engaged in leasing motor vehicles is not considered as coming into possession of the motor vehicles incident to the person's regular business.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(2)(b): A pawnbroker engaged in selling, exchanging, or pawning motor vehicles is considered as coming into possession of the motor vehicles incident to the person's regular business and must be licensed as a used motor vehicle dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(3): A person currently licensed as a dealer or salesperson by another state or country and not currently under license suspension or revocation by the administrator may only sell motor vehicles in this state to licensed dealers, dismantlers, or manufacturers, and only at their places of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(4): Except as otherwise expressly provided:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(4)(a): a direct-sale manufacturer is subject to the same provisions under this chapter as a new motor vehicle dealer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(4)(b): a direct-sale manufacturer salesperson is subject to the same provisions under this chapter as a salesperson.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(5): Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter to the contrary, a direct-sale manufacturer:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(5)(a): may, without a franchise, sell, display for sale, or offer for sale or exchange a motor vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(5)(a)(i): if the direct-sale manufacturer is an electric vehicle manufacturer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(5)(a)(ii): if the direct-sale manufacturer is a low-volume manufacturer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-103(5)(b): may not sell, display for sale, or offer for sale or exchange a new motor vehicle that is not of the same line-make the direct-sale manufacturer manufactures.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-104 Division creation -- Administrator appointed.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-104(1): There is created within the commission the Motor Vehicle Enforcement Division with the powers and duties provided in this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-104(2): The division shall be administered by the motor vehicle enforcement administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-104(3): The administrator shall be appointed by the commission and is subject to the commission's supervision and direction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-107 Attorney general -- Duty to render opinions and to represent or appear for administrator or board.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The attorney general shall:Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-107(1): represent the administrator, the division, and the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-107(2): give opinions on all questions of law relating to the interpretation of this chapter or arising out of the administration of this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-107(3): appear on behalf of the administrator, the division, or the board in all actions brought by or against the administrator, the division, or board, whether under the provisions of this chapter or otherwise.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-108 Copies of records and papers -- Admissibility in evidence.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Certified copies of all records and papers prepared in the office of the administrator under seal of the administrator are admissible in evidence in any case in the same manner as the original.
