Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5 Brokering of a new motor vehicle without a license prohibited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1): 41-3-202(1); 41-3-202(2); 41-3-202(1)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1)(a): 41-3-202(1); 41-3-202(2) A person may not, for a fee, commission, or other form of compensation, arrange, offer to arrange, or broker a transaction involving the sale or lease of more than two:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1)(a)(i): 41-3-202(1) new or used motor vehicles in any 12 consecutive month period, unless the person is licensed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1)(a)(ii): 41-3-202(2) used motor vehicles in any 12 consecutive month period, unless the person is licensed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1)(b): 41-3-202(1) Each transaction a person arranges, offers to arrange, or brokers involving the sale or lease of a motor vehicle for a fee, commission, or other form of compensation is a separate violation under this section if:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1)(b)(i): the person has for a fee, commission, or other form of compensation, arranged, offered to arrange, or brokered the sale or lease of more than two new or used motor vehicles within the previous 12 consecutive month period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(1)(b)(ii): 41-3-202(1) the person is not licensed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-201.5(2): A person who violates this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202 Licenses -- Classes and scope.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(1): A new motor vehicle dealer's license permits the licensee to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(1)(a): offer for sale, sell, or exchange new motor vehicles if the licensee possesses a franchise from the manufacturer of the motor vehicle offered for sale, sold, or exchanged by the licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(1)(b): offer for sale, sell, or exchange used motor vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(1)(c): operate as a body shop; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(1)(d): dismantle motor vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(2): A used motor vehicle dealer's license permits the licensee to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(2)(a): offer for sale, sell, or exchange used motor vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(2)(b): operate as a body shop; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(2)(c): dismantle motor vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(3): A direct-sale manufacturer's license permits the licensee to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(3)(a): offer for sale, sell, or exchange new motor vehicles of the same line-make that the direct-sale manufacturer manufactures;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(3)(b): offer for sale, sell, or exchange used motor vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(3)(c): operate as a body shop; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(3)(d): dismantle motor vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(4): A new motorcycle, off-highway vehicle, and small trailer  dealer's license permits the licensee to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(4)(a): offer for sale, sell, or exchange new motorcycles, off-highway vehicles, or small trailers if the licensee possesses a franchise from the manufacturer of the motorcycle, off-highway vehicle, or small trailer offered for sale, sold, or exchanged by the licensee;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(4)(b): offer for sale, sell, or exchange used motorcycles, off-highway vehicles, or small trailers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(4)(c): dismantle motorcycles, off-highway vehicles, or small trailers.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(5): A used motorcycle, off-highway vehicle, and small trailer  dealer's license permits the licensee to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(5)(a): offer for sale, sell, or exchange used motorcycles, off-highway vehicles, and small trailers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(5)(b): dismantle motorcycles, off-highway vehicles, or small trailers.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(6): (6)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(6)(a): (6)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(6)(b): A licensee that has been issued a salesperson's license and that is employed by a dealer that operates as a wholesale motor vehicle auction may be employed by more than one dealer that operates as a wholesale motor vehicle auction at a time.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(7)(a): A direct-sale manufacturer salesperson's license permits the licensee to act as a direct-sale manufacturer salesperson for one direct-sales manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-202(7)(b): A direct-sale manufacturer salesperson licensee may not simultaneously hold a salesperson's license.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203 Licenses -- Form -- Seal -- Custody of salesperson's license -- Display of salesperson and dealer licenses -- Licensee's pocket card.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1)(a): The administrator shall prescribe the form of each license and the seal of the administrator's office shall be imprinted on each license.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1)(b): The  administrator shall deliver or mail the  license of each salesperson to the dealer employing the salesperson and  the dealer shall keep the license in the dealer's custody and control and conspicuously display the license  in the dealer's place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1)(c): Each licensee shall display conspicuously the licensee's own license in the licensee's place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1)(d): In addition to the other provisions of this section, each direct-sale manufacturer licensee shall display conspicuously the licensee's own license in each of the licensee's:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1)(d)(i): showrooms; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(1)(d)(ii): authorized service centers.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(2)(a): The administrator shall prepare and deliver a pocket card, certifying that the person whose name is on the card is licensed under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(2)(b): Each salesperson's card shall also contain the name and address of the dealer employing the salesperson.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-203(2)(c): Each salesperson shall on request display the salesperson's pocket card.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204 Licenses -- Principal place of business as prerequisite -- Change of location -- Relinquishment on loss of principal place of business.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a): The following licensees must maintain a principal place of business:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(i): dealers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(ii): special equipment dealers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(iii): manufacturers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(iv): transporters;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(v): remanufacturers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(vi): dismantlers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(vii): crushers;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(viii): body shops; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(ix): distributors who:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(ix)(A): are located within the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(a)(ix)(B): have a branch office within the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(b): (1)(a) The administrator may not issue a license under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(c): If a licensee changes the location of the licensee's principal place of business, the licensee shall immediately notify the administrator and  the administrator shall issue  a new license for the unexpired portion of the term of the original license at no additional fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(1)(d): In addition to the other requirements of this section, if a direct-sale manufacturer licensee changes the location of an authorized service center of the licensee, the licensee shall immediately notify the administrator and the administrator shall issue a new license for the unexpired portion of the term of the original license at no additional fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(2)(a): If a licensee loses possession of a principal place of business, the license is automatically suspended and he shall immediately notify the administrator and upon demand by the administrator deliver the license, pocket cards, special plates, and temporary permits to the administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(2)(b): The administrator shall hold the licenses, cards, plates, and permits until the licensee obtains:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(2)(b)(i): a principal place of business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-204(2)(b)(ii): if the licensee is a direct-sale manufacturer, an authorized service center.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205 Licenses -- Bonds required -- Maximum liability -- Action against surety -- Loss of bond.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1): 41-3-301(1); 41-3-402(1)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(a): Before a dealer's, special equipment dealer's, crusher's, or body shop's license is issued, the applicant shall file with the administrator a corporate surety bond in the amount of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(a)(i): $50,000 until June 30, 2006, and $75,000 on or after July 1, 2006, for a motor vehicle dealer's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(a)(ii): $20,000 until June 30, 2006, and $75,000 on or after July 1, 2006, for a special equipment dealer's license;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(a)(iii): $10,000 for a motorcycle, off-highway vehicle, or small trailer dealer's or crusher's license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(a)(iv): $20,000 for a body shop's license.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(b): The corporate surety shall be licensed to do business within the state and have a rating of at least B+ by the A.M. Best Company.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(c): 41-3-301(1); 41-3-402(1) The form of the bond:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(c)(ii)(A): fraud;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(1)(d): The total aggregate liability on the bond to all persons making claims, regardless of the number of claimants or the number of years a bond remains in force, may not exceed the amount of the bond.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(2)(b): The surety or principal shall notify the administrator if a claim on the bond is successfully prosecuted or settled against the surety or principal.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-205(6): A representative or consignee of a dealer is not required to file a bond if the dealer for whom the representative or consignee acts fully complies with the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207 New motor vehicle dealer's license -- Change, addition, or loss of franchise -- Notification -- Relinquishment of license and relicensing as used motor vehicle dealer -- Continuance in business to dispose of stock.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207(1): If a dealer changes to, adds, cancels, or loses a franchise for the sale of new motor vehicles he shall immediately notify the administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207(2)(a): If the dealer has cancelled or lost a franchise, the administrator shall determine whether the dealer should be licensed as a used motor vehicle dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207(2)(b): If the administrator determines that the dealer should be licensed as a used motor vehicle dealer, he shall issue to the dealer a used motor vehicle dealer's license.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207(2)(c): A dealer relicensed as a used motor vehicle dealer may continue to sell new motor vehicles for up to six months from the date of the relicensing, to enable the dealer to dispose of his existing stock of new motor vehicles.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207.5 Liquidation of inventory for suspended used motor vehicle dealers.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207.5(1): A used motor vehicle dealer whose used motor vehicle dealer's license has been suspended may liquidate any remaining inventory by selling the remaining used motor vehicles to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207.5(1)(a): a licensed auto auction;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207.5(1)(b): another licensed motor vehicle dealer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207.5(1)(c): to any person, but only after the used motor vehicle has been titled in the name of the owner, partner, or corporate officer of the used motor vehicle dealer for at least 12 months.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-207.5(2): (1)(a); (b) A dealer may sell inventory under Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-208 Salesperson's license -- Relinquishment upon loss or change of employment -- Notice to salesperson -- New license required.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-208(1): If a salesperson is discharged from or leaves his employer, the dealer who last employed the salesperson shall return the salesperson's license to the administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-208(2): The salesperson shall be notified at his last known place of residence that his license has been returned to the administrator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-208(3): A person may not act as a motor vehicle salesperson until a new license is procured.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-209(1): If the administrator finds that an applicant is not qualified to receive a license, a license may not be granted.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-405 Sale of third party warranty or service contract -- Remission of fee.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-405(1): If a dealer licensed under this chapter sells a third party warranty or service contract to a customer, the dealer shall within 15 days remit the fee paid by the customer to the warranty or service contract company.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-405(2): Failure of a dealer to remit the fee within 15 days is a ground for dealer license suspension and allows the customer a cause of action against the dealer for damages that otherwise would have been covered by the warranty or service contract.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(1): "Buyback vehicle" means a motor vehicle with an alleged nonconformity that has been replaced or repurchased by a manufacturer as the result of a court judgment, arbitration, or any voluntary agreement entered into between the manufacturer or its agent and a consumer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(2): 13-20-5 "Consumer" means an individual who has entered into an agreement or contract for the transfer, lease, or purchase of a new motor vehicle other than for the purposes of resale, or sublease, during the duration of the period defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(3): "Manufacturer" means any manufacturer, importer, distributor, or anyone who is named as the warrantor on an express written warranty on a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4): 13-20-2; 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102; (4)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(a): 13-20-2; 41-1a-102 "Motor vehicle" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(a)(i): 13-20-2 a motor home, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(a)(ii): 41-1a-102 a motor vehicle, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(b): 41-1a-102; 41-1a-102; (4)(a)(i) "Motor vehicle" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(b)(i): those portions of a motor home designated, used, or maintained primarily as a mobile dwelling, office, or commercial space;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(b)(ii): 41-1a-102 farm tractor, motorcycle, road tractor, or truck tractor as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(b)(iii): 41-1a-102 mobile home as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(4)(b)(iv): (4)(a)(i) any motor vehicle with a gross laden weight of over 12,000 pounds, except a motor home as defined under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(5): Title 13, Chapter 20, New Motor Vehicle Warranties Act "Nonconforming vehicle" means a buyback vehicle that has been investigated and evaluated pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(6)(a): "Nonconformity" means a defect, malfunction, or condition that fails to conform to the express warranty, or substantially impairs the use, safety, or value of a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(6)(b): "Nonconformity" does not include a defect, malfunction, or condition that results from an accident, abuse, neglect, modification, or alteration of a motor vehicle by a person other than the manufacturer, its authorized agent, or a dealer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(7): "Seller" means any person selling, auctioning, leasing, or exchanging a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-407(8): 41-3-406; 41-3-413 "Violation" means each failure to comply with the obligations imposed by Sections


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408 Resale of buyback or nonconforming vehicles -- Disclosure statements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(1): (1)(a); (b)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(1)(a): A motor vehicle may not be offered, auctioned, sold, leased, transferred, or exchanged by a manufacturer or dealer with the knowledge that it is a buyback vehicle or a nonconforming vehicle without prior written disclosure in a clear and conspicuous manner, in accordance with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(1)(b): This section also applies to buyback vehicles or nonconforming vehicles originally returned to a manufacturer or its agent in another state and subsequently resold, leased, or offered or displayed for resale or lease in this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(1)(c): (1)(a); (b) An owner of a motor vehicle who is not a manufacturer or dealer, but who has been given information as required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2)(a): The following disclosure language shall be contained in each contract for the sale or lease of a buyback vehicle or a nonconforming vehicle to a consumer or shall be contained in a form affixed to a contract, lease, bill of sale, or any other document that transfers title:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2)(b): The text of the disclosure shall be printed in 12 point boldface type except the heading, which shall be in 16 point extra boldface type.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2)(c): The entire notice shall be boxed.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2)(d): Each nonconformity shall be listed separately on a numbered line.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2)(e): A seller must obtain the consumer's acknowledgment of this written disclosure prior to completing a sale, lease, or other transfer of title as evidenced by the consumer's signature within the box containing the disclosure.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(2)(f): Within 30 days after the sale, lease, or other transfer of title of a nonconforming vehicle, the seller shall deliver to the Motor Vehicle Division a copy of the signed written disclosure required for the sale, lease, or other transfer of title of the nonconforming vehicle.  The Motor Vehicle Division shall include the disclosure in the nonconforming vehicle's records.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(3)(a): There shall be affixed to the lower corner of the windshield furthest removed from the driver's side of a nonconforming vehicle, a disclosure statement form which shall be readily visible from the exterior of the vehicle. The form shall be in the following configuration and shall state:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(3)(b): The disclosure statement shall be at least 4-1/2 inches wide and 5 inches long.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(3)(c): The heading shall be boldface type in capital letters not smaller than 18 point in size and the body copy shall be regular or medium face type not smaller than 12 point in size.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(3)(d): Each nonconformity shall be listed separately on a numbered line.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-408(3)(e): The motor vehicle and title identification information must be inserted in the spaces provided.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-409 Certificate of title -- Brand -- Reporting requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A manufacturer, its agent, or a dealer who accepts the return of a nonconforming vehicle, shall:Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-409(1): immediately upon receipt, cause the words "MANUFACTURER BUYBACK NONCONFORMING VEHICLE" to be clearly and conspicuously stamped on the face of the original certificate of title, the Manufacturer's Statement of Origin, or other evidence of ownership; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-409(2): within 10 days of receipt of the certificate of title, Manufacturer's Statement of Origin, or other evidence of ownership, submit a copy of the face of that stamped document to the Motor Vehicle Division of the Tax Commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411 Private remedy.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(1): 41-3-406; 41-3-409 Any seller who violates Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(1)(a): actual damages if the purchaser elects to retain the buyback vehicle, or the value of the consideration paid for the buyback vehicle if the purchaser elects rescission;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(1)(b): the costs of the action and reasonable attorney fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(1)(c): up to three times the value of the actual damages or the consideration as exemplary damages; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(1)(d): other equitable relief, including rescission and restitution, the court determines to be proper in addition to damages and costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(2): Actual damages include the difference between the actual market value of the buyback vehicle or nonconforming vehicle at the time of purchase and the contract price, towing, repair, and storage expenses, rental of substitute transportation, food and lodging expenses, lost wages, finance charges, sales or use tax, other governmental fees, lease charges, and other incidental and consequential damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(3): Lack of privity is not a bar to any action under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(4): 41-3-410; 41-3-406; 41-3-409
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(4)(a): 41-3-410; 41-3-406; 41-3-409 A permanent injunction, final judgment, or final order of the court obtained by the attorney general under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(4)(b): This section does not apply to consent orders or stipulated judgments in which there is no admission of liability by the defendant.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-411(5): Any action to enforce liability under this section must be brought within two years from the date of discovery by the consumer of the facts underlying the cause of action.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-502 Special plates -- Permit to use dealer plate to demonstrate loaded motor vehicle.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-502(1): Under rules established by the administrator, the division may issue a permit to a dealer to use a dealer plate to demonstrate a loaded commercial vehicle over 26,000 pounds to a bona fide prospective purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-502(2): To obtain a permit, the dealer or his authorized representative shall apply on a form prescribed by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-502(3): If approved and issued, the permit shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-502(3)(a): carried in the commercial vehicle for which the division issued the permit during the demonstration trip; and

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-504 Special plates -- Display.
---------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-504(3): clearly legible; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-504(4): securely fastened in a horizontal position.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(1)(a): is not lawfully entitled to them;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(1)(b): has made or knowingly permitted illegal use of the plates;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(1)(c): has committed fraud in the registration of motor vehicles; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(1)(d): failed to give notices of sales or transfers required under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(2)(a): Suspension or revocation of special plates takes effect immediately upon written notification to the licensee by the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(2)(b): Upon notification, the licensee shall immediately return all special plates to the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(2)(c): Failure to return the plates or permitting their continued use is a violation of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(3)(a): If a licensee desires to appeal the division's suspension or revocation, he shall file a written notice of appeal with the administrator within 10 days of the suspension or revocation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(3)(b): Upon receipt of the notice, the administrator shall schedule a hearing for not more than 20 days from the date the written appeal is received.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(3)(c): The licensee may not continue to use or possess any special plates that have been suspended or revoked.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-508(3)(d): The hearing and subsequent appeal process are in accordance with the procedures in this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-703 Violations as felonies.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-703(1): A person may not forge, falsify, or counterfeit any license, special plate, temporary permit, in-transit permit, decal, or other document issued by the division or any other state or jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-703(2): A person may not hold or use any license, special plate, temporary permit, in-transit permit, decal, or other document issued by the division or any other state or jurisdiction knowing it to have been forged, falsified, or counterfeited.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-704 Penalty waiver.
----------------------------------------------
Upon making a record of its actions, and upon reasonable cause shown, the commission may waive, reduce, or compromise any of the civil penalties imposed by the division under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-801 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part shall be known as the "Consignment Sales Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-802 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-802(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-802(1)(a): "Consignee" means a dealer who accepts vehicles for sale under an agreement that the dealer will pay the consignor for any sold vehicle and will return any unsold vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-802(1)(b): "Consignee" does not include a wholesale motor vehicle auction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-802(2): "Consignor" means a person who places a vehicle with a consignee for consignment sale.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803 Consignment sales.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(1): (2) A consignor may take possession of his consigned vehicle at any time the consigned vehicle is in the possession of a consignee, provided that the consignor:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(1)(a): has notified the consignee in writing that he will take possession of the consigned vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(1)(b): (2) has paid all outstanding charges owing to the consignee that have been agreed to by the consignor in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(2): (1)(b) The agreed upon charges under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(2)(a): stated on a form designed by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(2)(b): included with the written consignment agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(3): A consignee who sells a consigned vehicle shall report to the consignor in writing the exact selling price of the consigned vehicle under either of the following circumstances:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(3)(a): the consignor and consignee agree in writing that the consignor shall receive a percentage of the selling price upon the sale of the vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(3)(b): the consignor and consignee renegotiate in writing the selling price of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(4): When a consignee sells a consigned vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(4)(a): the consignee, within seven calendar days of the date of sale, must give written notice to the consignor that the consigned vehicle has been sold; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(4)(b): the consignee, within 21 calendar days of the date of sale, or within 15 calendar days of receiving payment in full for the consigned vehicle, whichever date is earlier, shall remit the payment received to the consignor, unless the agreement to purchase the consigned vehicle has been rescinded before expiration of the 21 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(5): If the agreement to purchase the consigned vehicle has for any reason been rescinded before the expiration of 21 calendar days of the date of sale, the consignee shall within five calendar days thereafter give written notice to the consignor that the agreement to purchase has been rescinded.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(6): Vehicles on consignment shall be driven with the consignee's dealer plates. All other license plates or registration indicia must be removed from the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(7): Prior to driving a consigned vehicle on the consignee's dealer plates, the consignee and the consignor shall execute a written consignment agreement that states:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(7)(a): the party responsible for damage or misuse to a consigned vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(7)(b): the permitted uses a consignee may make of a consigned vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-3-803(8): The consignee shall keep the written consignment agreement on file at his principal place of business.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 41 - Chapter 4 - Financing Dealers and Purchasers
*****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-1 Agreements to finance through designated source which lessen competition or create monopoly declared void.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be unlawful for any person who is engaged, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture or distribution of motor vehicles, to sell or enter into a contract to sell motor vehicles, whether patented or unpatented, to any person who is engaged or intends to engage in the business of selling such motor vehicles at retail in this state, on the condition or with an agreement or understanding, either express or implied, that such person so engaged in selling motor vehicles at retail shall in any manner finance the purchase or sale of any one or number of motor vehicles only with or through a designated person or class of persons or shall sell and assign the conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases arising from the sale of motor vehicles or any one or number thereof only to a designated person or class of persons, when the effect of the condition, agreement or understanding so entered into may be to lessen or eliminate competition, or create or tend to create a monopoly in the person or class of persons who are designated, by virtue of such condition, agreement or understanding to finance the purchase or sale of motor vehicles or to purchase such conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases, and any such condition, agreement or understanding is hereby declared to be void and against the public policy of this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-2 Threat to discontinue sales to retail seller prima facie evidence of violation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any threat, expressed or implied, made directly or indirectly to any person engaged in the business of selling motor vehicles at retail in this state by any person engaged, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture or distribution of motor vehicles, that such person will discontinue or cease to sell, or refuse to enter into a contract to sell, or will terminate a contract to sell motor vehicles, whether patented or unpatented, to such person who is so engaged in the business of selling motor vehicles at retail, unless such person finances the purchase or sale of any one or number of motor vehicles only with or through a designated person or class of persons or sells and assigns the conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases arising from his retail sales of motor vehicles or any one or number thereof only to a designated person or class of persons shall be prima facie evidence of the fact that such person so engaged in the manufacture or distribution of motor vehicles has sold or intends to sell the same on the condition or with the agreement or understanding prohibited in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-3 Threat to discontinue sales to person engaged in business of financing who is affiliated with manufacturer or distributor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any threat, expressed or implied, made directly or indirectly, to any person engaged in the business of selling motor vehicles at retail in this state by any person, or any agent of any such person, who is engaged in the business of financing the purchase or sale of motor vehicles or of buying conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases on motor vehicles in this state and is affiliated with or controlled by any person engaged, directly or indirectly, in the manufacture or distribution of motor vehicles, that such person so engaged in such manufacture or distribution shall terminate his contract with or cease to sell motor vehicles to such person engaged in the sale of motor vehicles at retail in this state unless such person finances the purchase or sale of any one or number of motor vehicles only or through a designated person or class of persons or sells and assigns the conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages, or leases arising from his retail sale of motor vehicles or any one or any number thereof only to such person so engaged in financing the purchase or sale of motor vehicles or in buying conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases on motor vehicles, shall be presumed to be made at the direction of and with the authority of such person so engaged in such manufacture or distribution of motor vehicles, and shall be prima facie evidence of the fact that such person so engaged in the manufacture or distribution of motor vehicles has sold or intends to sell the same on the condition or with the agreement or understanding prohibited in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-4 Giving of gratuity by manufacturer or wholesaler to one financing sales which lessens competition, unlawful.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be unlawful for any person who is engaged, directly or indirectly, in the manufacture or wholesale distribution only of motor vehicles, whether patented or unpatented, to pay or give, or contract to pay or give any thing or service of value to any person who is engaged in the business of financing the purchase or sale of motor vehicles or of buying conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases on motor vehicles sold at retail within this state if the effect of any such payment or the giving of any such thing or service of value may be to lessen or eliminate competition, or tend to create or create a monopoly in the person or class of persons who receive or accept such thing or service of value.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-5 Unlawful for person financing sales to accept gratuity.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be unlawful for any person who is engaged in the business of financing the purchase or sale of motor vehicles or of buying conditional sales contracts, chattel mortgages or leases on motor vehicles sold at retail within this state to accept or receive, or contract or agree to accept or receive, either directly or indirectly, any payment, thing, or service of value from any person who is engaged, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture or wholesale distribution only of motor vehicles, whether patented or unpatented, if the effect of the acceptance or receipt of any such payment, thing, or service of value may be to lessen or eliminate competition, or to create or tend to create a monopoly in the person who accepts or receives such payment, thing, or service of value, or contracts or agrees to accept or receive the same.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-6 Accepting gratuity, unlawful thereafter to finance sales.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
It shall be unlawful for any person who hereafter so accepts or receives, either directly or indirectly, any payment, thing, or service of value, as set forth in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-7 Violation by corporation -- Penalty.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
For a violation of any of the provisions of this act by any corporation or association mentioned herein, it shall be the duty of the attorney general or the district attorney of the proper county, to institute proper suits or quo warranto proceedings in any court of competent jurisdiction for the forfeiture of its charter rights, franchises or privileges and powers exercised by such corporation or association, and for the dissolution of the same under the general statutes of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-8 Violation by foreign corporation -- Penalty.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Every foreign corporation, as well as every foreign association, exercising any of the powers, franchises, or functions of a corporation in this state, violating any of the provisions of this act, is hereby denied the right and prohibited from doing any business in this state, and it shall be the duty of the attorney general to enforce this provision by bringing proper proceedings by injunction or otherwise. The Division of Corporations and Commercial Code shall be authorized to revoke the license of any such corporation or association heretofore authorized by it to do business in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-9 Persons violating provisions -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this act, any person who is a party to any agreement or understanding, or to any contract prescribing any condition prohibited by this act, and any employee, agent or officer of any such person who shall participate, in any manner, in making, executing, enforcing, performing or in urging, aiding or abetting in the performance of any such contract, condition, agreement or understanding and any person who pays or gives or contracts to pay or give any thing or service of value prohibited by this act, and any person who receives or accepts or contracts to receive or accept any thing or service of value prohibited by this act, shall be deemed guilty of a felony and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50 nor more than $5,000, or be imprisoned not less than six months nor more than one year, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day's violation of this provision shall constitute a separate offense.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-10 Agreements in violation of provisions are void.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any contract or agreement in violation of the provisions of this act, shall be absolutely void and shall not be enforceable either in law or equity.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-11 Provisions cumulative.
----------------------------------------------------
The provisions hereof shall be held cumulative of each other and of all other laws in any way affecting them now in force in this state.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-12 Actions for damages.
--------------------------------------------------
In addition to the criminal and civil penalties herein provided, any person who is injured in his business or property by any other person or corporation or association or partnership, by reason of anything forbidden or declared to be unlawful by this act, may sue therefor in any court having jurisdiction thereof in the county where the defendant resides or is found, or any agent resides or is found, or where service may be obtained, without respect to the amount in controversy, and to recover twofold the damages by him sustained, and the costs of suit. Whenever it shall appear to the court before which any proceeding under this act is pending, that the ends of justice require that other parties shall be brought before the court, the court may cause them to be made parties defendant and summoned, whether they reside in the county where such action is pending, or not.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-13 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-13(1): The term "person," as used in this act, means any individual, firm, corporation, partnership, association, trustee, receiver or assignee for the benefit of creditors.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-13(2): The terms "sell," "sold," "buy," and "purchase," as used in this act, include exchange, barter, gift, and offer or contract to sell or buy.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-4-14 Severability clause.
--------------------------------------------------
If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this act is for any reason held to be unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this act. The Legislature hereby declares that it would have passed this act, and each section, subsection, sentence, clause and phrase thereof irrespective of the fact that any one or more other sections, subsections, sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 41 - Chapter 6a - Traffic Code
**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Traffic Code."

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(1): "Alley" means a street or highway intended to provide access to the rear or side of lots or buildings in urban districts and not intended for through vehicular traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(2): 41-22-2 "All-terrain type I vehicle" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(3)(b): police vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(3)(c): ambulances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(3)(d): other publicly or privately owned vehicles as designated by the commissioner of the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(4): 53-3-102 "Autocycle" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(a): "Bicycle" means a wheeled vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(a)(i): propelled by human power by feet or hands acting upon pedals or cranks;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(a)(ii): with a seat or saddle designed for the use of the operator;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(a)(iii): designed to be operated on the ground; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(a)(iv): whose wheels are not less than 14 inches in diameter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(b): "Bicycle" includes an electric assisted bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(5)(c): "Bicycle" does not include scooters and similar devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(6)(a): "Bus" means a motor vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(6)(a)(i): designed for carrying more than 15 passengers and used for the transportation of persons; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(6)(a)(ii): designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(6)(b): "Bus" does not include a taxicab.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(7)(a): "Circular intersection" means an intersection that has an island, generally circular in design, located in the center of the intersection where traffic passes to the right of the island.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(7)(b)(i): roundabouts;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(7)(b)(ii): rotaries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(7)(b)(iii): traffic circles.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(12): "Controlled-access highway" means a highway, street, or roadway:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(12)(a): designed primarily for through traffic; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(12)(b): to or from which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access, except at points as determined by the highway authority having jurisdiction over the highway, street, or roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13): "Crosswalk" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13)(a): that part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13)(a)(i)(A): the curbs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13)(a)(i)(B): in the absence of curbs, from the edges of the traversable roadway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13)(a)(ii): in the absence of a sidewalk on one side of the roadway, that part of a roadway included within the extension of the lateral lines of the existing sidewalk at right angles to the centerline; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(13)(b): any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(14): "Department" means the Department of Public Safety.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18): "Electric assisted bicycle" means a bicycle with an electric motor that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(a): has a power output of not more than 750 watts;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(b): has fully operable pedals on permanently affixed cranks;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(c): is fully operable as a bicycle without the use of the electric motor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d): is one of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(i): an electric assisted bicycle equipped with a motor or electronics that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(i)(A): provides assistance only when the rider is pedaling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(i)(B): ceases to provide assistance when the bicycle reaches the speed of 20 miles per hour;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(ii): an electric assisted bicycle equipped with a motor or electronics that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(ii)(A): may be used exclusively to propel the bicycle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(ii)(B): is not capable of providing assistance when the bicycle reaches the speed of 20 miles per hour; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(iii): an electric assisted bicycle equipped with a motor or electronics that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(iii)(A): provides assistance only when the rider is pedaling;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(18)(d)(iii)(C): is equipped with a speedometer.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(19)(a)(iii): an electric propulsion system with average power of one horsepower or 750 watts;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(19)(a)(iv): a maximum speed capacity on a paved, level surface of 12.5 miles per hour; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-102(19)(a)(v): a deck design for a person to stand while operating the device.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-203 Attempt, conspiracy, or other violations of chapter.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-203(1): A person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit, or aids or abets in the commission of an act that is a crime under this chapter, whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons or as a principal, agent, or accessory, is guilty of the offense.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-203(2): A person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly, or willfully induces, causes, coerces, requires, permits, or directs another to violate a provision of this chapter is guilty of the offense.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-204 Requiring or knowingly permitting driver to unlawfully operate vehicle.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person employing or otherwise directing the operator of a vehicle may not require or knowingly permit the operation of the vehicle on a highway in a manner contrary to law.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-205 Government-owned vehicles subject to chapter.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except as specifically exempted, the provisions of this chapter applicable to an operator of a vehicle on the highway apply to an operator of a vehicle owned or operated by the United States, this state or any county, city, town, district or any other political subdivision of the state.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-206 Conflict with Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations supercede any conflicting provisions of this chapter pertaining to commercial motor carriers.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-207 Uniform application of chapter -- Effect of local ordinances.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-207(1): The provisions of this chapter are applicable throughout this state and in all of its political subdivisions and municipalities.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-207(2): A local highway authority may not enact or enforce any rule or ordinance in conflict with the provisions of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-207(3): A local highway authority may adopt:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-207(3)(a): ordinances consistent with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-207(3)(b): additional traffic ordinances not in conflict with this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214 Quasi-public roads and parking areas -- Local ordinances.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(1): As used in this section, "quasi-public road or parking area" means a privately owned and maintained road or parking area that is generally held open for use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel or parking.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(2)(a): Any municipality or county may by ordinance provide that a quasi-public road or parking area within the municipality or county is subject to this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(2)(b): An ordinance may not be enacted under this section without:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(2)(b)(i): a public hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(2)(b)(ii): the agreement of a majority of the owners of the quasi-public road or parking area involved.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(3): 41-6a-215 This section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(3)(a): 41-6a-215 supercedes conflicting provisions under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(3)(b): does not require a peace officer to patrol or enforce any provisions of this chapter on any quasi-public road or parking area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-214(3)(c): does not affect the duty of a peace officer to enforce those provisions of this chapter applicable to private property other than under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-216 Removal of plants or other obstructions impairing view -- Notice to owner -- Penalty.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-216(1): The owner of real property shall remove from his property any tree, plant, shrub, or other obstruction, or part of it that constitutes a traffic hazard by obstructing the view of an operator of a vehicle on a highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-216(2): When a highway authority determines on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that a traffic hazard exists, it shall notify the owner and order that the hazard be removed within 10 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-216(3): The failure of the owner to remove the traffic hazard within 10 days is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-306 Pedestrian traffic-control signals -- Rights and duties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-306(1): A pedestrian facing a steady "Walk" or symbol of "Walking Person" of a pedestrian traffic-control signal has the right-of-way and may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-306(2): A pedestrian facing a flashing "Don't Walk" or "Upraised Hand" of a pedestrian traffic-control signal may not start to cross the roadway in the direction of the signal, but a pedestrian who has partially completed crossing on the walk signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-306(3): A pedestrian facing a steady "Don't Walk" or "Upraised Hand" of a pedestrian traffic-control signal may not enter the roadway in the direction of the signal.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-306(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-307 Flashing red or yellow signals -- Rights and duties of operators -- Railroad grade crossings excluded.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-307(1): 41-6a-1203 Except as provided under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-307(1)(a): operator of a vehicle facing an illuminated flashing red stop signal used in a traffic-control signal or with a traffic sign shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the nearest side of the intersection, or if none, then at a point nearest the intersecting roadway where the operator has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-307(1)(b): right to proceed is subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-307(1)(c): operator of a vehicle facing an illuminated flashing yellow caution signal may cautiously proceed through the intersection or cautiously proceed past the signal.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-307(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308 Lane use control signals -- Colors.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308(1): The operator of a vehicle facing a traffic-control signal placed to control individual lane use shall obey the signal as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308(1)(a): Green signal -- vehicular traffic may travel in any lane over which a green signal is shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308(1)(b): Steady yellow signal -- vehicular traffic is warned that a lane control change is being made.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308(1)(c): Steady red signal -- vehicular traffic may not enter or travel in any lane over which a red signal is shown.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308(1)(d): Flashing yellow signal -- vehicular traffic may use the lane only for the purpose of approaching and making a left turn.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-308(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401 Accident involving property damage -- Duties of operator, occupant, and owner -- Exchange of information -- Notification of law enforcement -- Penalties.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(1)(a): "Knowledge" or "with knowledge" means, with respect to an individual's own conduct or to circumstances surrounding an individual's conduct, that the individual is aware of the nature of the conduct or the existing circumstances.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(1)(b): "Reason to believe" means information from which a reasonable person would believe that the person may have been involved in an accident.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2): (2)(a)(i); (2)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(a): (2)(a)(i) The operator of a vehicle with knowledge that the operator was involved in, or who has reason to believe that the operator may have been involved in, an accident resulting only in damage to another vehicle or other property:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(a)(i): may move the vehicle as soon as possible:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(a)(i)(A): out of the travel lanes on any roadway to an adjacent shoulder, the nearest suitable cross street, or other suitable location that does not obstruct traffic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(a)(i)(B): off the freeway main lines, shoulders, medians, or adjacent areas to the nearest safe location on an exit ramp shoulder, a frontage road, the nearest suitable cross street, or other suitable location that does not obstruct traffic; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(a)(ii): (2)(a)(i) shall remain at the scene of the accident or the location described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(b): (2)(a)(i) Moving a vehicle as required under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(2)(c): If the operator has knowledge that the operator was involved in, or reason to believe that the operator may have been involved in, an accident resulting in damage to another vehicle or other property only after leaving the scene of the accident, the operator shall immediately comply as nearly as possible with the requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3): (6) Except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(a): give to the persons involved:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(a)(i): the operator's name, address, and the registration number of the vehicle being operated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(a)(ii): the name of the insurance provider covering the vehicle being operated including the phone number of the agent or provider; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(b): upon request and if available, exhibit the operator's license to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(b)(i): any investigating peace officer present;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(b)(ii): the operator, occupant of, or person attending the vehicle or other property damaged in the accident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(3)(b)(iii): the owner of property damaged in the accident, if present.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(4): The operator of a vehicle involved in an accident shall immediately and by the quickest means of communication available give notice or cause to give notice of the accident to the nearest office of a law enforcement agency if the accident resulted in property damage to an apparent extent of $2,500 or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(5): (6) Except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(5)(a): locate and notify the operator or owner of the vehicle or the owner of other property damaged in the accident of the operator's name, address, and the registration number of the vehicle causing the damage; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(5)(b): attach securely in a conspicuous place on the vehicle or other property a written notice giving the operator's name, address, and the registration number of the vehicle causing the damage.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(6): The operator of a vehicle that provides the information required under this section to an investigating peace officer at the scene of the accident is exempt from providing the information to other persons required under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401(7): An operator of a vehicle that has knowledge or has reason to believe that the operator may have been involved in an accident and fails to comply with the provisions of this section is guilty of a class B misdemeanor.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401.9 Authority to remove and dispose of vehicles and cargoes of vehicles involved in accidents.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401.9(1): As a result of a motor vehicle accident, a law enforcement agency with jurisdiction may, without the consent of the owner or carrier, remove a vehicle, cargo, or other personal property that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401.9(1)(a): has been damaged or spilled within the right-of-way or any portion of a roadway on the state highway system;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401.9(1)(b): is blocking the roadway; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401.9(1)(c): is otherwise endangering public safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-401.9(2): The Department of Transportation, a law enforcement agency, or an authorized tow truck motor carrier shall not be held responsible for any damages or claims that result from exercising any authority or the failure to exercise any authority granted under this section provided they are acting in good faith.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-402(1): The department may require any operator of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or total property damage to the apparent extent of $2,500 or more to file within 10 days after the request:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(1): As used in this section, "government entity" means the Department of Transportation, the Utah Highway Patrol Division, or a local government entity or agency.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(2)(b): (6) may only charge the individual for the actual cost or a reasonable estimate of the cost of services provided in responding to the motor vehicle accident, limited to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(2)(b)(i): medical costs for transporting an individual from the scene of a motor vehicle accident or treating a person injured in a motor vehicle accident;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(2)(b)(ii): (6) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(2)(b)(iii): the cost of materials used in cleaning up the motor vehicle accident, if the individual is legally liable for the motor vehicle accident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(2)(b)(iv): towing costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(3): If a government entity imposes a charge on more than one individual for the actual cost or a reasonable estimate of the cost of responding to a motor vehicle accident, the government entity shall apportion the charges so that the government entity does not receive more for responding to the motor vehicle accident than the actual response cost or a reasonable estimate of the cost.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(4): Nothing in this section prohibits a government entity from contracting with an independent contractor to recover costs related to damage to public property.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-409(5): If a government entity enters into a contract with an independent contractor to recover costs related to damage to public property, the government entity may only pay the independent contractor out of any recovery received from the person who caused the damage or the responsible party.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-502 Driving under the influence of alcohol, drugs, or a combination of both or with specified or unsafe blood alcohol concentration -- Penalities -- Reporting of convictions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-502(1): An actor commits driving under the influence if the actor operates or is in actual physical control of a vehicle within this state if the actor:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-502(1)(a): has sufficient alcohol in the actor's body that a subsequent chemical test shows that the actor has a blood or breath alcohol concentration of .05 grams or greater at the time of the test;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-502(1)(b): is under the influence of alcohol, any drug, or the combined influence of alcohol and any drug to a degree that renders the actor incapable of safely operating a vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-502(1)(c): has a blood or breath alcohol concentration of .05 grams or greater at the time of operation or actual physical control.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5 Sobriety program for DUI.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a): "24-7 sobriety program" means a 24 hours a day, seven days a week sobriety and drug monitoring program that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a)(i): requires an individual to abstain from alcohol or drugs for a period of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a)(ii): requires an individual to submit to random drug testing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a)(iii): requires the individual to be subject to testing to determine the presence of alcohol:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a)(iii)(A): twice a day at a central location where timely sanctions may be applied;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a)(iii)(B): by continuous remote sensing or transdermal alcohol monitoring by means of an electronic monitoring device that allows timely sanctions to be applied; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(a)(iii)(C): by an alternate method that is approved by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(i): "Testing" means a procedure for determining the presence and level of alcohol or a drug in an individual's breath or body fluid, including blood, urine, saliva, or perspiration.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii): "Testing" includes any combination of the use of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(A): remote and in-person breath testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(B): drug patch testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(C): urinalysis testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(D): saliva testing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(E): continuous remote sensing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(F): transdermal alcohol monitoring; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(1)(b)(ii)(G): alternate body fluids approved for testing by the commissioner of the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(2): The department may establish a 24-7 sobriety program with a law enforcement agency that is able to meet the 24-7 sobriety program qualifications and requirements under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(a): The 24-7 sobriety program shall include use of multiple testing methodologies for the presence of alcohol or drugs that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(a)(i): best facilitates the ability to apply timely sanctions for noncompliance;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(a)(ii): is available at an affordable cost; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(a)(iii): provides for positive, behavioral reinforcement for program compliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(b): The commissioner shall consider the following factors to determine which testing methodologies are best suited for each participant:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(b)(i): whether a device is available;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(b)(ii): whether the participant is capable of paying the fees and costs associated with each testing methodology;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(b)(iii): travel requirements based on each testing methodology and the participant's circumstances;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(b)(iv): the substance or substances for which testing will be required; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(3)(b)(v): other factors the commissioner considers relevant.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4): 41-6a-501(2); 41-6a-501(2); 41-6a-502
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(a): The 24-7 sobriety program shall be supported by evidence of effectiveness and satisfy at least two of the following categories:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(a)(i): the program is included in the federal registry of evidence-based programs and practices;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(a)(ii): the program has been reported in a peer-reviewed journal as having positive effects on the primary targeted outcome; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(a)(iii): the program has been documented as effective by informed experts and other sources.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(b): If a law enforcement agency participates in a 24-7 sobriety program, the department shall assist in the creation and administration of the program in the manner provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(c): A 24-7 sobriety program shall have at least one testing location and two daily testing times approximately 12 hours apart.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(d): 41-6a-501(2) A person who is ordered by a judge to participate in the 24-7 sobriety program for a first conviction as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(4)(e): 41-6a-501(2); 41-6a-502 If a person who is ordered by a judge to participate in the 24-7 sobriety program has a prior conviction as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(5): (4)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(5)(a): If a law enforcement agency participates in a 24-7 sobriety program, the law enforcement agency may designate an entity to provide the testing services or to take any other action required or authorized to be provided by the law enforcement agency pursuant to this section, except that the law enforcement agency's designee may not determine whether an individual is required to participate in the 24-7 sobriety program.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(5)(b): (4)(c) Subject to the requirement in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(6): (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(6)(a): The commissioner of the department shall establish a data management technology plan for data collection on 24-7 sobriety program participants.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(6)(b): All required data related to participants in the 24-7 sobriety program shall be received into the data management technology plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.5(6)(c): (6) The data collected under this Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-515.6 Field sobriety test training.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Each law enforcement agency shall ensure that each peace officer receives training on the current standard field sobriety testing guidelines established by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518 Ignition interlock devices -- Use and monitoring -- Probationer to pay cost -- Indigency -- Fee.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1): 41-6a-507(2); (3) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(a): "Commissioner" means the commissioner of the Department of Public Safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(b): "Employer verification" means written verification from the employer that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(b)(i): the employer is aware that the employee is an interlock restricted driver;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(b)(ii): the vehicle the employee is operating for employment purposes is not made available to the employee for personal use;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(b)(iii): the business entity that employs the employee is not entirely or partly owned or controlled by the employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(b)(iv): the employer's auto insurance company is aware that the employee is an interlock restricted driver; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(b)(v): the employee has been added to the employer's auto insurance policy as an operator of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-518(1)(c): "Ignition interlock system" or "system" means a constant monitoring device or any similar device certified by the commissioner that prevents a motor vehicle from being started or continuously operated without first determining the driver's breath alcohol concentration.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601 Speed regulations -- Safe and appropriate speeds at certain locations -- Prima facie speed limits -- Emergency power of the governor.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1): A person may not operate a vehicle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions, giving regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing, including when:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1)(a): approaching and crossing an intersection or railroad grade crossing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1)(b): approaching and going around a curve;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1)(c): approaching a hill crest;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1)(d): traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1)(e): traveling in, through, or approaching other hazards that exist due to pedestrians, other traffic, weather, or highway conditions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(1)(f): the speed causes the person to fail to maintain control of the vehicle or stay within a single lane of travel.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(2): (1); (4); 41-6a-602; 41-6a-603; 41-6a-303 Subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(2)(a): 41-6a-303 20 miles per hour in a reduced speed school zone as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(2)(b): 25 miles per hour in any urban district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(2)(c): 55 miles per hour in other locations.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(3): 41-6a-604; 41-6a-602; 41-6a-603 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-601(4): (1); 76-3-301.5

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602 Speed limits established on state highways.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(a): The Department of Transportation shall determine the reasonable and safe speed limit for each highway or section of highway under its jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(b): For each highway or section of highway, each speed limit shall be based on a traffic engineering and safety study consistent with the requirements and recommendations in the most current version of the "Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices."
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(c): The traffic engineering and safety studies shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(c)(i): the design speed;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(c)(ii): prevailing vehicle speeds;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(c)(iii): accident history;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(c)(iv): highway, traffic, and roadside conditions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(1)(c)(v): other highway safety factors.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(2): The Department of Transportation may establish different speed limits on a highway or section of highway based on:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(2)(a): time of day;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(2)(b): highway construction;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(2)(c): type of vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(2)(d): weather conditions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(2)(e): other highway safety factors.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(3): (3)(b); (c); (3)(c); (3)(b); (3)(b); (3)(c); (3); (1); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(3)(a): (3)(b); (c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-602(3)(b): (3)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
