Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608 Photo radar -- Restrictions on use.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(1): "Photo radar" means a device used primarily for highway speed limit enforcement substantially consisting of a low power doppler radar unit and camera mounted in or on a vehicle, which automatically produces a photograph of a vehicle traveling in excess of the legal speed limit, with the vehicle's speed, the date, time of day, and location of the violation printed on the photograph.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2): Photo radar may not be used except:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(a)(i): in school zones; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(a)(ii): in other areas that have a posted speed limit of 30 miles per hour or less;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(b): when a peace officer is present with the photo radar unit;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(c): when signs are posted on the highway providing notice to a motorist that photo radar may be used;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(d): when use of photo radar by a local highway authority is approved by the local highway authority's governing body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(2)(e): when the citation is accompanied by the photograph produced by photo radar.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(3): (2) The restrictions under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(4): A contract or agreement regarding the purchase, lease, rental, or use of photo radar by the department or by a local highway authority may not specify any condition for issuing a citation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(5): The department and any local highway authority using photo radar, upon request, shall make the following information available for public inspection during regular office hours:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(5)(a): the terms of any contract regarding the purchase, lease, rental, or use of photo radar;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(5)(b): the total fine revenue generated by using photo radar;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(5)(c): the number of citations issued by the use of photo radar; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(5)(d): the amount paid to the person providing the photo radar unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-608(6): 53-3-102 A moving traffic violation obtained through the use of photo radar is not a reportable violation as defined under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609 Radar jamming devices and jamming radar prohibited -- Defense -- Exceptions -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(1): As used in this section, "radar jamming device" means any instrument or mechanism designed or intended to interfere with the radar or any laser that is used by law enforcement personnel to measure the speed of a motor vehicle on a highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(2)(a): A person may not operate a motor vehicle on a highway with a radar jamming device in the motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(2)(b): A person may not knowingly use a radar jamming device to interfere with the radar signals or lasers used by law enforcement personnel to measure the speed of a motor vehicle on a highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(3): (2)(a) It is an affirmative defense to a charge under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(4): This section does not apply to law enforcement personnel acting in their official capacity.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-609(5): A person who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705 Passing on right -- When permissible.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705(1): 41-6a-718 Subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705(1)(a): when the vehicle overtaken is making or preparing to make a left turn; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705(1)(b): on a roadway with unobstructed pavement of sufficient width for two or more lines of vehicles moving lawfully in the direction being traveled by the overtaking vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705(2): The operator of a vehicle may overtake and pass another vehicle on the right only under conditions permitting the movement with safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705(3): Except for a person operating a bicycle, the operator of a vehicle may not overtake and pass another vehicle if the movement is made by driving off the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-705(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5 Definitions -- Operation of motor vehicle near a vulnerable user of a highway prohibited -- Endangering a vulnerable user of a highway prohibited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1): As used in this section, "vulnerable user of a highway" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(a): a pedestrian, including a person engaged in work upon a highway or upon utilities facilities along a highway or providing emergency services within the right-of-way of a highway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(b): a person riding an animal; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c): a person operating any of the following on a highway:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(i): a farm tractor or implement of husbandry, without an enclosed shell;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(ii): a skateboard;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(iii): roller skates;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(iv): in-line skates;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(v): a bicycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(vi): an electric-assisted bicycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(vii): an electric personal assistive mobility device;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(viii): a moped;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(ix): a motor assisted scooter;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(x): a motor-driven cycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(xi): a motorcycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(xii): a manual wheelchair; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(1)(c)(xiii): a golf cart.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-706.5(2): An operator of a motor vehicle may not knowingly, intentionally, or recklessly:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-709 One-way traffic.
------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-709(3): A person operating a vehicle in a roundabout shall operate the vehicle only to the right of the roundabout island.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-712 Divided highway -- Use of right-hand side -- Crossing only where permitted.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-712(1): A person operating a vehicle on a divided highway shall use the right-hand roadway unless directed or permitted to use another roadway by a traffic-control device or a peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-712(2): A person operating a vehicle may not operate the vehicle over, across, or within any dividing space, median, or barrier of a divided highway, except when:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-712(2)(a): authorized by a traffic-control device or a peace officer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-712(2)(b): operating a tow truck in response to a customer service call and the tow truck motor carrier has already received authorization from the local law enforcement agency in the jurisdiction where the vehicle to be towed is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-712(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-715 Controlled-access highways -- Prohibiting use by class or kind of traffic -- Traffic-control devices.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-715(1): A highway authority may regulate or prohibit the use of any controlled-access highway within its respective jurisdiction by any class or kind of traffic which is found to be incompatible with the normal and safe movement of traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-715(2): A highway authority may restrict traffic on a highway to specific vehicle equipment of capabilities due to weather conditions for the safe movement of traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-715(3): The highway authority shall erect and maintain traffic-control devices on the controlled-access highway on which the regulations or prohibitions are applicable.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-717 Use of runaway vehicle ramps.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-717(1): A person may not use a runaway vehicle ramp unless the person is in an emergency situation requiring the use of the ramp to stop the person's vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-717(2): A person may not stop, stand, or park a vehicle on a runaway vehicle ramp or in the pathway of the runaway vehicle ramp.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-717(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801 Turning -- Manner -- Traffic-control devices.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
The operator of a vehicle shall make turns as follows, and a violation of this section is an infraction:Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(1): Right turns: both a right turn and an approach for a right turn shall be made as close as practical to the right-hand curb or edge of the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(2): Left turns:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(2)(a): the operator of a vehicle intending to turn left shall approach the turn from the extreme left-hand lane for traffic moving in the same direction;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(2)(b): whenever practicable, shall be made by turning onto the roadway being entered in the extreme left-hand lane for traffic moving in the new direction, unless otherwise directed by a traffic-control device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(2)(c): may be made on a highway across solid double yellow line pavement markings indicating a two-direction, no-passing zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3): (3)(c)(ii); (3)(c)(ii) Two-way left turn lanes:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(a): where a two-way left turn lane is provided, a left turn may not be made from any other lane;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(b): a vehicle may not be driven in the two-way left turn lane except when preparing for or making:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(b)(i): a left turn from or into the roadway; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(b)(ii): a U-turn except when prohibited by a traffic-control device;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(c): (3)(c)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(c)(i): (3)(c)(ii) except as provided under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(c)(ii): if traffic in the two-way left turn lane extends beyond 500 feet, the operator of a vehicle intending to turn left may enter the two-way left turn lane immediately upon reaching the last vehicle in the two-way left turn lane;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(d): (3)(c)(ii) the operator of a vehicle that has turned left into the two-way left turn lane may not travel in the lane more than 500 feet unless the operator intends to turn left and Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-801(3)(e): the operator of a vehicle may not travel straight through an intersection in a two-way left turn lane.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-802(1): As used in this section, "railroad grade crossing" means the area between the passive or active warning signs where a railroad track and roadway intersect.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-802(2): The operator of a vehicle may not make a U-turn or turn the vehicle to proceed in the opposite direction:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-802(2)(a): unless the movement can be made safely and without interfering with other traffic;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-802(2)(b): on any curve, or upon the approach to, or near the crest of a grade, if the vehicle is not visible at a distance of 500 feet by the operator of any other vehicle approaching from either direction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-802(2)(c): on a railroad track or railroad grade crossing.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-803 Moving a vehicle -- Safety.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-803(1): A person may not move a vehicle which is stopped, standing, or parked until the movement may be made with reasonable safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-803(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-804(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-804(1)(a): A person may not turn a vehicle, merge into a continuing lane from a lane of travel that is ending, or otherwise move right or left on a roadway or change lanes until:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901 Right-of-way between vehicles -- Unregulated intersection.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(1): The operator of a vehicle approaching an intersection not regulated by a traffic-control device shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle that has entered the intersection from a different highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(2): (3) Except as specified in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(2)(a): more than one vehicle enters or approaches an intersection from different highways at approximately the same time; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(2)(b): the intersection:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(2)(b)(i): is not regulated by a traffic-control device;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(2)(b)(ii): is not regulated because the traffic-control signal is inoperative; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(2)(b)(iii): is regulated from all directions by stop signs.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(3): The operator of a vehicle approaching an intersection not regulated by a traffic-control device:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(3)(a): from a highway that does not continue beyond the intersection, shall yield the right-of-way to the operator of any vehicle on the intersecting highway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(3)(b): from a highway that is not paved, shall yield the right-of-way to the operator of any vehicle on a paved intersecting highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-901(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903 Yield right-of-way -- Vehicle turning left -- Entering or crossing highway other than from another roadway -- Merging lanes.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903(1): The operator of a vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903(1)(a): intending to turn to the left shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is so close to the turning vehicle as to constitute an immediate hazard;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903(1)(b): about to enter or cross a highway from any place other than another highway shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the highway to be entered or crossed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903(1)(c): traveling in a lane that is about to merge into a continuing lane, shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles traveling in the continuing lane and which are so close as to be an immediate hazard.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1 Right-of-way -- Zipper merge.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(1)(a): "Merge point" means the point at which two traffic lanes merge into one traffic lane.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(1)(b): "Zipper method" means a method of merging vehicles at a merge point that involves the operators of the merging vehicles:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(1)(b)(i): using both lanes of traffic until the vehicles reach the merge point; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(1)(b)(ii): once the vehicles reach the merge point, alternating yielding the right-of-way into the single traffic lane.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(2): An operator of a vehicle shall use the zipper method when merging at a congested merge point.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-903.1(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1003 Pedestrians yielding right-of-way -- Limits on pedestrians.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1003(1): A pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles on the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1003(2): A pedestrian crossing a roadway at a point where there is a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles on the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1003(3): Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals are in operation, a pedestrian may not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005 Limitation on pedestrians related to railroad grade crossings or bridges.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(1): As used in this section, "active railroad grade crossing" means a railroad grade crossing when:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(1)(a): the gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(1)(b): warning lights are flashing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(1)(c): audible warning devices are being sounded; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(1)(d): other traffic control devices signal the approach of a railroad train.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(2): A pedestrian may not pass through, around, over, or under or remain on a crossing gate or barrier at an active railroad grade crossing or bridge.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(3): A pedestrian may not enter or remain within the area between a railroad track and a railroad sign or signal if the railroad grade crossing is active.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(4): A pedestrian may not occupy or remain on a railroad grade crossing when the railroad sign or signal is not active except to cross the railroad crossing on a designated walkway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1005(5): A pedestrian may not remain in an area between railroad signs or signals, railroad gates, or rail crossing arms if the railroad grade crossing is active.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1008 Vehicle crossing sidewalk -- Operator to yield.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The operator of a vehicle crossing a sidewalk shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and all other traffic on the sidewalk.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011 Pedestrian vehicles.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(a)(i): "Pedestrian vehicle" means a self-propelled conveyance designed, manufactured, and intended for the exclusive use of a person with a physical disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(a)(ii): A "pedestrian vehicle" may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(a)(ii)(A): exceed 48 inches in width;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(a)(ii)(B): have an engine or motor with more than 300 cubic centimeters displacement or with more than 12 brake horsepower; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(a)(ii)(C): be capable of developing a speed in excess of 30 miles per hour.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(1)(b): "Physical disability" means any bodily impairment which precludes a person from walking or otherwise moving about as a pedestrian.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(2): A pedestrian vehicle operated by a person with a physical disability is exempt from vehicle registration, inspection, and operator license requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(3): (3); (3); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(3)(a): A person with a physical disability may operate a pedestrian vehicle with a motor of not more than .5 brake horsepower capable of developing a speed of not more than eight miles per hour:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(3)(a)(i): on the sidewalk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(3)(a)(ii): in all places where pedestrians are allowed.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(3)(b): (3) A permit, license, registration, authority, application, or restriction may not be required or imposed on a person with a physical disability who operates a pedestrian vehicle under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1011(3)(c): (3); (2) The provisions of this Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1101 Parents and guardians may not authorize child's violation of chapter.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The parent or guardian of a child may not authorize or knowingly permit the child to violate any of the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1104 Persons on bicycles, mopeds, skates, and sleds not to attach to moving vehicles -- Exception.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1104(1): A person riding a bicycle, moped, coaster, skate board, roller skates, sled, or toy vehicle may not attach it or a person to any moving vehicle on a highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1104(2): This section does not prohibit attaching a trailer or semitrailer to a bicycle or moped if that trailer or semitrailer has been designed for attachment.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105 Operation of bicycle or moped on and use of roadway -- Duties, prohibitions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1): A person operating a bicycle or a moped on a roadway at less than the normal speed of traffic at the time and place and under the conditions then existing shall ride as near as practicable to the right-hand edge of the roadway except when:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(a): overtaking and passing another bicycle or vehicle proceeding in the same direction;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(b): preparing to make a left turn at an intersection or into a private road or driveway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(c): traveling straight through an intersection that has a right-turn only lane that is in conflict with the straight through movement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d): reasonably necessary to avoid conditions that make it unsafe to continue along the right-hand edge of the roadway including:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(i): fixed or moving objects;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(ii): parked or moving vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(iii): bicycles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(iv): pedestrians;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(v): animals;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(vi): surface hazards; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(1)(d)(vii): a lane that is too narrow for a bicycle and a vehicle to travel safely side by side within the lane.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(2): A person operating a bicycle or moped on a highway shall operate in the designated direction of traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(3)(a): A person riding a bicycle or moped on a roadway may not ride more than two abreast with another person except on paths or parts of roadways set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(3)(b): (3)(a) If allowed under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(4): If a usable path for bicycles has been provided adjacent to a roadway, a bicycle rider may be directed by a traffic-control device to use the path and not the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5): (5); (6)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(a): (5) As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(b): (6) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(b)(i): the individual slows to a reasonable speed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(b)(ii): yields the right-of-way to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(b)(ii)(A): any pedestrian within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(b)(ii)(B): other traffic within the intersection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1105(5)(b)(ii)(C): oncoming traffic that poses an immediate hazard during the time the individual is traveling through the intersection.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106 Bicycles and human powered vehicle or device to yield right-of-way to pedestrians on sidewalks, paths, or trails -- Uses prohibited -- Negligent collision prohibited -- Speed restrictions -- Rights and duties same as pedestrians.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(1): A person operating a bicycle or a vehicle or device propelled by human power shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(1)(a): yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(1)(b): give an audible signal before overtaking and passing a pedestrian.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(2): A person 18 years of age or older may not operate a bicycle or a vehicle or device propelled by human power on a sidewalk, path, or trail, or across a roadway in a crosswalk, where prohibited by a traffic-control device or ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(3): A person may not operate a bicycle or a vehicle or device propelled by human power in a negligent manner so as to collide with a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(3)(a): pedestrian; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(3)(b): person operating a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(3)(b)(i): bicycle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(3)(b)(ii): vehicle or device propelled by human power.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(4): A person operating a bicycle or a vehicle or device propelled by human power on a sidewalk, path, or trail, or across a driveway, or across a roadway on a crosswalk may not operate at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions, giving regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1106(5): (1); (4) Except as provided under Subsections


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107 Bicycles -- Parking on sidewalk, roadway -- Prohibitions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(1): A person may park a bicycle on a sidewalk unless prohibited or restricted by a traffic-control device.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(2): A bicycle parked on a sidewalk may not impede the normal and reasonable movement of pedestrian or other traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(3): A bicycle may be parked on the roadway at any location where parking is allowed:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(3)(a): at any angle to the curb or edge of the roadway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(3)(b): abreast of another bicycle or bicycles near the side of the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(4): A bicycle may not be parked on a roadway in a manner as to obstruct the movement of a legally parked motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1107(5): Part 14, Stopping, Standing, and Parking In all other respects, bicycles parked anywhere on a highway shall conform with the provisions of

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1108(2)(a): A person riding a bicycle or moped intending to turn left shall approach the turn as close as practicable to the right curb or edge of the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1108(2)(b): After proceeding across the intersecting roadway, to the far corner of the curb or intersection of the roadway edges, the bicyclist or moped operator shall stop, as far out of the way of traffic as practical.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1108(2)(c): After stopping, the bicyclist or moped operator shall yield to any traffic proceeding in either direction along the roadway he had been using.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1108(2)(d): After yielding and complying with any traffic-control device or peace officer regulating traffic, the bicyclist or moped operator may proceed in the new direction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1109 Bicycles and mopeds -- Turn signals -- Exceptions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1110 Bicycle and moped inspections -- At request of officer.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A peace officer may at any time require a person riding a bicycle or moped to stop and submit the bicycle or moped to an inspection and a test as appropriate if the officer has reasonable cause to believe that:Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1110(1): the bicycle or moped is unsafe or not equipped as required by law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1110(2): the bicycle or moped's equipment is not in proper adjustment or repair.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111 Bicycle racing -- When approved -- Prohibitions -- Exceptions -- Authorized exemptions from traffic laws.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(1): 41-6a-606 Bicycle racing on highways is prohibited under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(2)(a): Bicycle racing on a highway is permitted when a racing event is approved by a highway authority on a highway under its jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(2)(b): Approval of bicycle highway racing events may be granted only under conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(2)(b)(i): which assure reasonable safety for all race participants, spectators, and other highway users; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(2)(b)(ii): which prevent unreasonable interference with traffic flow which would seriously inconvenience other highway users.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(3): Participants in an approved bicycle highway racing event may be exempted from compliance with any traffic laws otherwise applicable:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(3)(a): by agreement with the approving highway authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1111(3)(b): if traffic control is adequate to assure the safety of all highway users.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1112 Bicycles and mopeds -- Carrying bundle -- One hand on handlebars.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1112(1): A person operating a bicycle or moped may not carry any package, bundle, or article which prevents the use of both hands in the control and operation of the bicycle or moped.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1112(2): A person operating a bicycle or moped shall keep at least one hand on the handlebars at all times.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1113 Bicycle -- Prohibited equipment -- Brakes required.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1113(1): A bicycle may not be equipped with, and a person may not use on a bicycle, a siren or whistle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1113(2): Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake or brakes which enable its driver to stop the bicycle within 25 feet from a speed of 10 miles per hour on dry, level, clean pavement.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1114(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1114(1)(b)(i): rear facing red reflector that is visible for 500 feet when directly in front of lawful lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1114(1)(b)(ii): rear facing red lamp that is designed for use on a bicycle and that emits flashing or nonflashing light visible from a distance of 500 feet to the rear.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1114(2): 41-6a-1603 A bicycle when in use or a person operating a bicycle at the times described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1114(2)(a): reflective material of sufficient size and reflectivity to be visible from both sides for 500 feet when directly in front of lawful lower beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1114(2)(b): a lamp that emits light visible from both sides from a distance of at least 500 feet.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115 Motor assisted scooters -- Conflicting provisions -- Restrictions -- Penalties.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1): 41-6a-1501; 41-6a-1506; 41-6a-1502(1); 53-3-202
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(a): Except as otherwise provided in this section, a motor assisted scooter is subject to the provisions under this chapter for a bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(b): 41-6a-1501; 41-6a-1506; 41-6a-1502(1); 53-3-202 For a person operating a motor assisted scooter, the following provisions do not apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(b)(i): 41-6a-1501 seating positions under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(b)(ii): 41-6a-1506 required lights, horns, and mirrors under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(b)(iii): 41-6a-1502(1) entitlement to full use of a lane under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(b)(iv): 53-3-202 driver licensing requirements under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(c): A person may operate a motor assisted scooter across a roadway in a crosswalk, except that the person may not operate the motor assisted scooter in a negligent manner in the crosswalk:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(c)(i): so as to collide with a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(c)(i)(A): pedestrian; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(c)(i)(B): person operating a bicycle or vehicle or device propelled by human power; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(1)(c)(ii): at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the existing conditions, giving regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(2): A person under eight years of age may not operate a motor assisted scooter with the motor running on any public property, highway, path, or sidewalk.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(3): 41-6a-1115.1(3) A person may not operate a motor assisted scooter:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(3)(a): in a public parking structure;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(3)(b): on public property posted as an area prohibiting bicycles;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(3)(c): while carrying more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(3)(d): that has been structurally or mechanically altered from the original manufacturer's design, except for an alteration by, or done at the request of, a person who rents the motor assisted scooter to lower the maximum speed for the motor assisted scooter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(3)(e): 41-6a-1115.1(3) at a speed of greater than 15 miles per hour or in violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(4): Except where posted or prohibited by local ordinance, a motor assisted scooter is considered a nonmotorized vehicle if it is being used with the motor turned off.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(5): An owner may not authorize or knowingly permit a person under the age of 18 to operate a motor assisted scooter in violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115(6): A person who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1 Scooter-share programs -- Local ordinances regulating motor assisted scooters.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(1): For the purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(1)(a): "Local authority" means a county, city, town, or metro township.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(1)(b): "Scooter-share operator" means a person offering a shared scooter for hire.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(1)(c): "Scooter-share program" means the offering of a shared scooter for hire.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(1)(d): "Shared scooter" means a motor assisted scooter offered for hire.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(2): A local authority may regulate the operation of a motor assisted scooter within its jurisdiction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(3): A local authority may authorize the operation of a motor assisted scooter on sidewalks and regulate the operation, including the maximum speed on the sidewalks.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(4): A regulation adopted by a local authority pursuant to this section regarding the operation of a motor assisted scooter shall be consistent with the regulation of bicycles and this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5): (5); Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(a): (5) A local authority may regulate the operation of a scooter-share program within its jurisdiction.  Regulation of scooter-share programs shall be consistent with this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(b): A shared scooter shall bear a single unique alphanumeric identification visible from a distance of five feet, that may not be obfuscated by branding or other markings, and that shall be used throughout the state, including by local authorities, to identify the shared scooter.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(c): A scooter-share operator shall maintain the following insurance coverage dedicated exclusively for operation of shared scooters:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(c)(i): commercial general liability insurance coverage with a limit of at least $1,000,000 each occurrence and $5,000,000 aggregate;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(c)(ii): automobile insurance coverage with a limit of at least $1,000,000 each occurrence and $1,000,000 aggregate;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(c)(iii): umbrella or excess liability coverage with a limit of at least $5,000,000 each occurrence and $5,000,000 aggregate; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(c)(iv): when the scooter-share operator employs an individual, workers' compensation coverage of no less than required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(d): Penalties for a moving or parking violation involving a motor assisted scooter or a shared scooter shall be assessed to the person responsible for the violation, and may not exceed penalties assessed to a rider of a bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(e): A scooter-share operator may be required to pay fees, provided that the total amount of the fees collected may not exceed the reasonable and necessary cost to the local authority of administering scooter-share programs, including a reasonable fee for the use of the right-of-way, commensurate and proportional to fees charged for similar uses.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(f): A scooter-share operator may be required to indemnify the local authority for claims, demands, costs, including reasonable attorney fees, losses, or damages brought against the local authority, and arising out of a negligent act, error, omission, or willful misconduct by the scooter-share operator or the scooter-share operator's employees, except to the extent the claims, demands, costs, losses, or damages arise out of such local authority's negligence or willful misconduct.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(g): In the interests of safety and right-of-way management, a local authority may designate locations where scooter-share operators may not stage shared scooters, provided that at least one location shall be permitted on each side of each city block in commercial zones and business districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(h): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act A local authority may require scooter-share operators, as a condition for operating a scooter-share program, to provide to the local authority anonymized fleet and ride activity data for completed trips starting or ending within the jurisdiction of the local authority on a vehicle of the scooter-share operator or of any person or company controlled by, controlling, or under common control with the scooter-share operator, provided that, to ensure individual privacy the trip data:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(h)(i): is provided via an application programming interface, subject to the scooter-share operator's license agreement for such interface, in compliance with a national data format specification;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(h)(ii): provided shall be treated as trade secret and proprietary business information, and may not be shared to third parties without the scooter-share operator's consent, and may not be treated as owned by the local authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(h)(iii): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act shall be considered private information, and may not be disclosed under
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(i): In regulating a shared scooter or a scooter-share program, a local authority may not impose any unduly restrictive requirement on a scooter-share operator, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(i)(i): requiring operation below cost; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.1(5)(i)(ii): subjecting riders of shared scooters to requirements more restrictive than those applicable to riders of privately owned motor assisted scooters or bicycles.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5 Electric assisted bicycles -- Restrictions -- Penalties.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(1): Except as otherwise provided in this section, an electric assisted bicycle is subject to the provisions under this chapter for a bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(2): An individual may operate an electric assisted bicycle on a path or trail designated for the use of a bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(3)(a): A local authority or state agency may adopt an ordinance or rule to regulate or restrict the use of an electric assisted bicycle, or a specific classification of an electric assisted bicycle, on a sidewalk, path, or trail within the jurisdiction of the local authority or state agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(3)(b): When enacting ordinances or making rules related to the use of a pathway or soft-surface trail, and during the planning or construction of a pathway or soft-surface trail, a local authority or state agency shall consider accommodations and increased trail access by a person with a mobility disability.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(4): An individual under 16 years old may not operate a class 3 electric assisted bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(5): An individual under 14 years old may not operate an electric assisted bicycle with the electric motor engaged on any public property, highway, path, or sidewalk unless the individual is under the direct supervision of the individual's parent or guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(6): An individual under eight years old may not operate an electric assisted bicycle with the electric motor engaged on any public property, highway, path, or sidewalk.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(7): The owner of an electric assisted bicycle may not authorize or knowingly permit an individual to operate an electric assisted bicycle in violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(8): 41-6a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(8)(a): Beginning January 1, 2017, each Utah-based manufacturer of an electric assisted bicycle and each distributor of an electric assisted bicycle in Utah shall permanently affix a label in a prominent location on the electric assisted bicycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(8)(b): 41-6a-102 Each manufacturer and each distributer shall ensure that the label is printed in Arial font, in 9-point type or larger, and includes the:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(8)(b)(i): 41-6a-102 appropriate electric assisted bicycle classification number described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(8)(b)(ii): top assisted speed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(8)(b)(iii): wattage of the motor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1115.5(9): An individual who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(1): 41-6a-1501; 41-6a-1506; 41-6a-1502(1); 53-3-202
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(1)(a): Except as otherwise provided in this section, an electric personal assistive mobility device is subject to the provisions under this chapter for a bicycle, moped, or a motor-driven cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(1)(b): 41-6a-1501; 41-6a-1506; 41-6a-1502(1); 53-3-202 For a person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device, the following provisions do not apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(1)(b)(i): 41-6a-1501 seating positions under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(1)(b)(ii): 41-6a-1506 required lights, horns, and mirrors under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(1)(b)(iv): 53-3-202 driver licensing requirements under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(2): A person under 15 years of age may not operate an electric personal assistive mobility device using the motor unless the person is under the direct supervision of the person's parent or guardian.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(3): A person may not operate an electric personal assistive mobility device:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(3)(a): on a highway consisting of a total of four or more lanes designated for regular vehicular traffic;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(3)(b): on a highway with a posted speed limit greater than 35 miles per hour; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(3)(c): that has been structurally or mechanically altered from the original manufacturer's design.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(4): An owner may not authorize or knowingly permit a person to operate an electric personal assistive mobility device in violation of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(5)(a): exceed a speed which is greater than is reasonable or prudent having due regard for weather, visibility, and pedestrians; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(5)(b): endanger the safety of other persons or property.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(6): A person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device shall yield to a pedestrian or other person using a mobility aid.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(7): (7)(a)(i); (ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(7)(a): An electric personal assistive mobility device may be operated on:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(7)(a)(i): a path or trail designed for the use of a bicycle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(7)(a)(ii): on a highway where a bicycle is allowed if the speed limit on the highway does not exceed 35 miles per hour.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(7)(b): (7)(a)(i); (ii) A person operating an electric personal assistive mobility device in an area described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(8): A person may operate an electric personal assistive mobility device at night if the device is equipped with or the operator is wearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(8)(a): a lamp pointing to the front that emits a white light visible from a distance of not less than 300 feet in front of the device; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(8)(b): front, rear, and side reflectors.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(9): A person may not operate an electric personal assistive mobility device while carrying an article that prevents the person from keeping both hands on the handlebars or interferes with the person's ability to safely operate the electric personal assistive mobility device.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(10): Only one person may operate an electric personal assistive mobility device at a time.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(11): A person may not park an electric personal assistive mobility device on a highway or sidewalk in a manner that obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116(12): A person who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1116.5 Local ordinances regulating electric personal assistive mobility devices.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A local authority may adopt an ordinance to regulate or restrict the use of electric personal assistive mobility devices.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1117 Mini-motorcycle restrictions -- Exceptions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1117(1): Title 41, Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act; Title 53, Chapter 3, Uniform Driver License Act A person may not operate a mini-motorcycle on any public property, highway, path, or sidewalk unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1117(1)(a): Title 41, Chapter 1a, Motor Vehicle Act the mini-motorcycle is registered for highway use in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1117(1)(b): Title 53, Chapter 3, Uniform Driver License Act the operator is licensed to operate a motorcycle in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1117(2): An owner may not authorize or knowingly permit a person to operate a mini-motorcycle in violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1117(3): A person who violates this section is guilty of an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118 Mobility vehicles.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1): 53-3-103; (3) As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(a): 53-3-103 "Division" means the Driver License Division created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(b): (3) "Mobility vehicle" means a vehicle that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(b)(i): is certified by the division for use by a person with a physical disability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(b)(ii): (3) complies with the requirements specified by the division in rules made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(c): "Mobility vehicle certification" means evidence that a vehicle meets the requirements for certification by the division as a mobility vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(d): "Mobility vehicle permit" means a permit issued by the division granting authority and specifying the conditions for a person with a physical disability to operate a mobility vehicle on a public highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(1)(e): "Physical disability" means a substantial impairment in one or more major life activities that prevents an individual from qualifying to obtain a license certificate.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(2): (3) A person may operate a mobility vehicle on a public highway in accordance with rules made by the division under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3)(a): establishing procedures for certification of a vehicle to be operated as a mobility vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3)(b): specifying the vehicle requirements for a vehicle to qualify as a mobility vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3)(c): for acceptable documentation of a mobility vehicle permit applicant's identity, Social Security number if applicable, Utah resident status, and Utah residence address;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3)(d): establishing procedures for the issuance of a mobility vehicle permit to an individual with a physical disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3)(e): for examining applicants for a mobility vehicle permit, as necessary for the safety and welfare of the applicant and the traveling public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(3)(f): granting authority and specifying the conditions and restrictions for a person to operate a mobility vehicle on a public highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(4): 53-3-105; (1)(e) An application for a mobility vehicle permit shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(4)(a): made upon a form furnished by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(4)(b): 53-3-105 accompanied by a nonrefundable fee set under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(4)(c): (1)(e) accompanied by a medical questionnaire form that includes information:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(4)(c)(i): (1)(e) that establishes the applicant has a physical disability as defined under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(4)(c)(ii): to determine whether it would be a public safety hazard to permit the applicant to drive a mobility vehicle on a public highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(5): An application and fee for a mobility vehicle permit entitle the applicant to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(5)(a): not more than three attempts to pass both the knowledge and skills tests within six months of the date of application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(5)(b): a mobility vehicle permit after all tests are passed and requirements are completed.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(6): A mobility vehicle permit expires on the birth date of the applicant in the fifth year following the year the mobility vehicle permit was issued.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1118(7): A person may not hold both a license certificate and a mobility vehicle permit.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119 Personal delivery device.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1): 72-7-502; 41-6a-1120; 41-26-102.1 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(a): "Eligible entity" means a corporation, partnership, association, firm, sole proprietorship, or other entity engaged in a business that includes the operation of a personal delivery device.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(b): 72-7-502 "Main-traveled way" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(c): "Pedestrian area" means a sidewalk, crosswalk, school crosswalk, school crossing zone, or safety zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d): 41-6a-1120; 41-26-102.1
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(i): "Personal delivery device" means an electrically powered device to which all of the following apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(i)(A): the device is manufactured for transporting cargo and goods; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(i)(B): the device is equipped with automated driving technology, including hardware and software, that enables the operation of the device with or without active control or monitoring by a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(ii): 41-6a-1120 A mobile carrier as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(iii): 41-26-102.1 "Personal delivery device" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(iii)(A): a motor vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(d)(iii)(B): 41-26-102.1 an ADS-dedicated vehicle as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(e)(i): "Personal delivery device operator" means an employee or agent of an eligible entity who exercises active physical control over, or monitoring of, the navigation and operation of a personal delivery device.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(e)(ii): "Personal delivery device operator" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(e)(ii)(A): with respect to a delivery or other service rendered by a personal delivery device, the person who requests the delivery or service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(1)(e)(ii)(B): a person who only arranges for and dispatches a personal delivery device for a delivery or other service.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2): An eligible entity may operate a personal delivery device so long as all of the following requirements are met:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(a): the personal delivery device is operated at a maximum speed of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(a)(i): 10 miles per hour when in a pedestrian area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(a)(ii): 20 miles per hour on a highway in an area that is not a pedestrian area;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(b): the eligible entity maintains an insurance policy that includes general liability coverage of not less than $100,000 for damages arising from the operation of the personal delivery device by the eligible entity and any agent of the eligible entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(c): the personal delivery device is equipped with all of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(c)(i): a marker that clearly identifies the name and contact information of the eligible entity operating the personal delivery device and a unique identification number;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(c)(ii): a braking system that enables the personal delivery device to come to a controlled stop; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(2)(c)(iii): if the personal delivery device is being operated between sunset and sunrise, a light on both the front and rear of the personal delivery device that is visible on all sides of the personal delivery device in clear weather from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and rear of the personal delivery device when directly in front of low beams of headlights on a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(3): A personal delivery device operator may not allow a personal delivery device to do any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(3)(a): fail to comply with traffic or pedestrian control devices and signals;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(3)(b): unreasonably interfere with pedestrians or traffic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(3)(c): transport hazardous material that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(3)(c)(i): regulated under 49 U.S.C. Chapter 51, Transportation of Hazardous Material; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(3)(c)(ii): required to be placarded under 49 C.F.R., Part 172, Subpart F, Placarding.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4): (4)(b); (4)(a); (4)(a); (4)(a); (b)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(a): (4)(b) When operating on a highway, the personal delivery device:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(a)(i): shall operate as close as practicable to the edge of the highway in the direction of authorized traffic movement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(a)(ii): (4)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(b): (4)(a); (4)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(b)(i): if practical and with due regard for safety and traffic conditions may temporarily operate in the main-traveled way to avoid a parked car or other obstacle on the edge of the highway; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(b)(ii): (4)(a) shall return to the edge of the highway as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(c): (4)(a); (b) Notwithstanding Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(c)(i): highway with a speed limit of 45 miles per hour or higher; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(4)(c)(ii): limited access highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(5): A personal delivery device has the rights and obligations applicable to a pedestrian under the same circumstances, except that a personal delivery device shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(6): A person may not operate a personal delivery device unless the person complies with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(7): (3) An eligible entity is responsible for both of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(7)(a): a violation of this section that is committed by a personal delivery device operator operated for the benefit of the eligible entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(7)(b): (3) any other circumstance, including a technological malfunction, in which a personal delivery device operates in a manner prohibited by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(8)(a): Following discussions with and input from eligible entities, a local authority or political subdivision may reasonably regulate the operation of personal delivery devices on a highway or pedestrian area.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(8)(b): This section does not affect the authority of a peace officer of a local authority or political subdivision to enforce the laws of this state relating to the operation of a personal delivery device.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1119(9): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120 Mobile carrier device.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1): "Mobile carrier" means an electrically powered device that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1)(a): is operated on a sidewalk or crosswalk;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1)(b): is intended primarily for the transport of property while remaining within 25 feet of the human operator;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1)(c): weighs less than 150 pounds, excluding cargo;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1)(d): has a maximum speed of 12.5 miles per hour;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1)(e): is equipped with a technology to transport personal property with the active monitoring of a personal property owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(1)(f): is primarily designed to remain within 25 feet of the personal property owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(2): 41-6a-1119 A mobile carrier is not a vehicle or personal delivery device as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(3): A mobile carrier may be operated on a sidewalk or crosswalk if all of the following requirements are met:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(3)(a): the mobile carrier is operated in accordance with the local ordinances, if any, established by the local highway authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(3)(b): the mobile carrier remains at all times within 25 feet of the human operator while the mobile carrier is in motion;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(3)(c): the mobile carrier is equipped with a braking system that enables the mobile carrier to come to a controlled stop; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(3)(d): if the mobile carrier is being operated between sunset and sunrise, a light on both the front and rear of the mobile carrier that is visible on all sides of the mobile carrier in clear weather from a distance of at least 500 feet to the front and rear of the mobile carrier when directly in front of low beams of headlights on a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(4): A personal property owner monitoring the mobile carrier may not allow a mobile carrier to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(4)(a): fail to comply with a traffic or pedestrian control device or signal;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(4)(b): unreasonably interfere with a pedestrian or traffic;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(4)(c): transport hazardous material; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(4)(d): operate on a street or highway, except when crossing the street or highway within a crosswalk.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(5): A mobile carrier has the rights and obligations applicable to a pedestrian under the same circumstances, except that a mobile carrier shall yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian on a sidewalk or crosswalk.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(6): A personal property owner may not operate a mobile carrier unless the person complies with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1120(7): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1201 Driving on tracks.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1201(1): The operator of a vehicle proceeding on any track in front of a railroad train on a highway shall remove the vehicle from the track as soon as practicable after signal from the operator of the train.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1201(2): When a railroad train has started to cross an intersection, an operator of a vehicle may not drive:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1201(2)(a): on or across the tracks; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1201(2)(b): in the path of the train within the intersection in front of the train.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1201(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1202 Driving through safety zone.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1202(1): The operator of a vehicle may not drive through or within a safety zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1202(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203 Railroad grade crossing -- Duty to stop -- Malfunctions and school buses -- Driving through, around, or under gate or barrier prohibited.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(1): 41-6a-1005 As used in this section, "active railroad grade crossing" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2): Whenever a person operating a vehicle approaches a railroad grade crossing, the operator of the vehicle shall stop within 50 feet but not less than 15 feet from the nearest rail of the railroad track and may not proceed if:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(a): a clearly visible electric or mechanical signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a railroad train or other on-track equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(b): a crossing gate is lowered, or when a human flagman gives or continues to give a signal of the approach or passage of a railroad train or other on-track equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(c): a railroad train or other on-track equipment approaching within approximately 1,500 feet of the highway crossing:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(c)(i): emits an audible signal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(c)(ii): the railroad train or other on-track equipment is an immediate hazard because of the railroad train's or other on-track equipment's speed or proximity to the crossing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(d): an approaching railroad train or other on-track equipment is plainly visible and is in hazardous proximity to the crossing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(2)(e): there is any other condition that makes it unsafe to proceed through the crossing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3)(a): An operator of a vehicle who suspects a false activation or malfunction of a railroad grade crossing signal device where there is no gate or barrier may drive a vehicle through the railroad grade crossing after stopping if:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3)(a)(i): the operator of a vehicle has a clear line of sight of at least one mile of the railroad tracks in all directions;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3)(a)(ii): there is no evidence of an approaching railroad train or other on-track equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3)(a)(iii): the vehicle can cross over the tracks safely; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3)(a)(iv): the operator of a school bus is compliant with written district policy.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(3)(b): As soon as is reasonably possible, the operator of a school bus shall notify the driver's dispatcher and the dispatcher shall notify the owner of the railroad track where the grade crossing signal device is located of the false activation or malfunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(4)(a): A person may not drive a vehicle through, around, or under a crossing gate or barrier at an active railroad grade crossing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(4)(b): A person may not cause a non-rail vehicle, whether or not occupied, to pass through, around, over, or under or remain on a gate or barrier at an active railroad grade crossing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(4)(c): A person may not cause a non-rail vehicle, whether or not occupied, to pass around, through, over, or under or remain in a rail or fixed guideway right-of-way in a manner that would cause a railroad train or other rail vehicle to make contact with the non-rail vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1203(5): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204 Trains -- Interference with vehicles limited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1): A person or government agency may not operate a train in a manner to prevent vehicular use of a roadway for a period of time in excess of five consecutive minutes except:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(a): when necessary to comply with signals affecting the safety of the movement of trains;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(b): when necessary to avoid striking any object or person on the track;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(c): when the train is disabled;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(d): when the train is in motion or while engaged in switching operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(e): when there is no vehicular traffic waiting to use the crossing;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(f): when necessary to comply with a governmental safety regulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(1)(g): as determined by a highway authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1204(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205 Railroad grade crossings -- Certain vehicles must stop -- Exceptions -- Rules.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1): 53-3-102; (2) An operator of a commercial motor vehicle, as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1)(a): (2) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1)(b): stop within 50 feet, but not closer than 15 feet, from the nearest rail of the railroad track before reaching the crossing if the tracks are not clear;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1)(c): obey all traffic control devices or the directions of a peace officer, or other  crossing official at the crossing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1)(d): before proceeding over a railroad grade crossing:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1)(d)(i): ensure that the vehicle has sufficient space to drive completely through a railroad grade crossing without stopping; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(1)(d)(ii): ensure that the vehicle has sufficient undercarriage clearance to safely and completely pass through the crossing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(a): shall stop within 50 feet, but not closer than 15 feet, from the nearest rail of the railroad track before crossing, at grade, any track of a railroad;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(b): while stopped, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(b)(i): look in both directions along the railroad track for:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(b)(i)(A): a sign of an approaching railroad train or other on-track equipment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(b)(i)(B): a signal indicating the approach of a railroad train or other on-track equipment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(b)(ii): listen for a signal indicating the approach of a railroad train or other on-track equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(c): may proceed across the railroad track only when reasonably safe to cross; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(2)(d): after stopping and safely proceeding, may not manually shift gears while crossing the railroad track.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(3): This section does not apply at a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(3)(a): railroad grade crossing where traffic is controlled by a peace officer or other crossing official;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(3)(b): railroad grade crossing where traffic is regulated by a traffic-control signal;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(3)(c): railroad grade crossing where a traffic-control device gives notice that the stopping requirements of this section are not applicable; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(3)(d): other railroad grade crossings excluded under 49 CFR 392.10.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1205(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206 Railroad crossing duties respecting crawler type tractor, power shovel, derrick, or other equipment or structure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1): A person may not operate or move the following on or across any tracks at a railroad grade crossing without first complying with this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(a): a crawler type tractor;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(b): a  power shovel;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(c): a  derrick;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(d): a  roller; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(e): any equipment or structure having:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(e)(i): normal operating speed of 10 or less miles per hour; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(e)(ii): a vertical body or load clearance of less than:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(e)(ii)(A): 1/2 inch per foot of the distance between any two adjacent axles; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(1)(e)(ii)(B): in any event, nine inches measured above the level surface of a roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(2): (1) A person intending to operate or move a vehicle or equipment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(2)(a): notice of the person's intended crossing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(2)(b): reasonable time to provide proper protection at the railroad grade crossing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3): (1) Before making a crossing under this section, a person operating or moving a vehicle or equipment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(a): shall first stop within 50 feet but not closer than 15 feet from the nearest rail of the railway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(b): while stopped, shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(b)(i): look in both directions along the railroad track for:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(b)(i)(A): a sign of an approaching railroad train or other on-track equipment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(b)(i)(B): a signal indicating the approach of a railroad train or other on-track equipment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(b)(ii): listen for a signal indicating the approach of a railroad train or other on-track equipment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(3)(c): may proceed across the track only when the crossing can be made safely.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(4): (1) A person operating or moving a vehicle or equipment described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1206(5): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301 Standards and specifications for lighting and special warning devices on school buses.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(1)(a): A school bus shall be equipped with red signal lamps mounted as high and as widely spaced laterally as practicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(1)(b): The red signal lamps shall display two alternately flashing red lights, located at the same level, to the front and rear of the school bus.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(1)(c): The red signal lamps shall be visible at 500 feet in normal sunlight.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(2)(a): A school bus shall be equipped with yellow signal lamps mounted near each of the four red signal lamps and at the same level but closer to the vertical centerline of the bus.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(2)(b): The yellow signal lamps shall display two alternately flashing yellow lights to the front and rear of the school bus.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(2)(c): The yellow signal lamps shall be visible at 500 feet in normal sunlight.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(3): A school bus driver shall activate the yellow signal lamps at least 100 feet, but not more than 500 feet, before every stop at which the alternately flashing red lights are activated.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1301(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.
