Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401 Standing or parking vehicles -- Restrictions and exceptions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1): 63C-9-102; 63C-9-201 Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law, the directions of a peace officer, or a traffic-control device, a person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a): stop, stand, or park a vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(i): on the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(ii): on a sidewalk;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(iii): within an intersection;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(iv): on a crosswalk;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(v): between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(vi): alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing, or parking would obstruct traffic;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(vii): on any bridge or other elevated structure, on a highway, or within a highway tunnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(viii): on any railroad tracks;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(ix): on any controlled-access highway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(x): in the area between roadways of a divided highway, including crossovers; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(a)(xi): any place where a traffic-control device prohibits stopping, standing, or parking;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b): 63C-9-102; 63C-9-201 stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger or passengers:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(i): in front of a public or private driveway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(ii): within 15 feet of a fire hydrant;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(iii): within 20 feet of a crosswalk;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(iv): within 30 feet upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign, yield sign, or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(v): within 20 feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within 75 feet of the entrance when properly signposted;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(vi): at any place where a traffic-control device prohibits standing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(vii): 63C-9-102; 63C-9-201 at the capitol hill complex as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(vii)(A): 63C-9-201 approval by the executive director of the State Capitol Preservation Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(b)(vii)(B): a properly displayed placard or other identifying marker approved by the executive director of the State Capitol Preservation Board to indicate this approval; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(c): park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading property or passengers:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(c)(i): within 50 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(1)(c)(ii): at any place where traffic-control devices prohibit parking.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(2): A person may not move a vehicle that is not lawfully under the person's control into any prohibited area or into an unlawful distance from the curb.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1401(3): This section does not apply to a tow truck motor carrier responding to a customer service call if the tow truck motor carrier has already received authorization from the local law enforcement agency in the jurisdiction where the vehicle to be towed is located.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402 Stopping or parking on roadways -- Angle parking -- Traffic-control devices prohibiting or restricting.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(1): Except as otherwise provided in this section, a vehicle stopped or parked on a two-way roadway shall be stopped or parked with the right-hand wheels:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(1)(a): parallel to and within 12 inches of the right-hand curb; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(1)(b): as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2): Except when otherwise provided by local ordinance, a vehicle stopped or parked on a one-way roadway shall be stopped or parked parallel to the curb or edge of the roadway in the direction of authorized traffic movement with its:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2)(a): right-hand wheels:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2)(a)(i): within 12 inches of the right-hand curb; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2)(a)(ii): as close as practicable to the right edge of the right-hand shoulder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2)(b): left-hand wheels:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2)(b)(i): within 12 inches of the left-hand curb; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(2)(b)(ii): as close as practicable to the left edge of the left-hand shoulder.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(3): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(3)(a): (3)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(3)(b): Angle parking is not permitted on any federal-aid or state highway unless the Department of Transportation has determined that the roadway is of sufficient width to permit angle parking without interfering with the free movement of traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(4): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(4)(a): The Department of Transportation, with respect to highways under its jurisdiction, may place traffic-control devices prohibiting or restricting the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles on a highway where:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1402(4)(a)(i): the stopping, standing, or parking is dangerous to those using the highway; or

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403 Motor vehicle left unattended -- Requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403(1): A person operating or in charge of a motor vehicle may not permit the vehicle to stand unattended without:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403(1)(a): stopping the engine;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403(1)(b): locking the ignition and removing the key;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403(1)(c): placing the transmission in "park" or the gears in "low" or "reverse" if the vehicle has a manual shift; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403(1)(d): effectively setting the brakes thereon.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1403(2): A person shall turn  the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway when standing a vehicle on any perceptible grade.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404 Stopping or parking on roadway outside business or residential district.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404(1): Outside a business or residence district, a person may not stop, park, or leave standing a vehicle, whether attended or unattended, on the roadway when it is practical to stop, park, or leave the vehicle off the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404(2): A person who stops, parks, or leaves a vehicle standing on a roadway shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404(2)(a): leave an unobstructed width of the highway opposite the vehicle for the free passage of other vehicles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404(2)(b): leave the vehicle so that other vehicle operators have a clear view of the stopped vehicle from a distance of 200 feet in each direction on the roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404(3): 41-6a-1401; 41-6a-1402 This section and Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1404(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408 Abandoned vehicles -- Removal by peace officer -- Report -- Vehicle identification.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(1): As used in this section, "abandoned vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor" means a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor that is left unattended:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(1)(a): on a highway or on or in the waters of the state for a period in excess of 48 hours; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(1)(b): on public or private property for a period in excess of seven days without express or implied consent of the owner or person in lawful possession or control of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(2): A person may not abandon a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor on a highway or on or in the waters of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(3): A person may not abandon a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor on public or private property without the express or implied consent of the owner or person in lawful possession or control of the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(4): 41-6a-1406; 73-18-20.1 A peace officer who has reasonable grounds to believe that a vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor has been abandoned may remove the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor or cause it to be removed in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(5): If the motor number, manufacturer's number or identification mark of the abandoned vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor has been defaced, altered or obliterated, the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor may not be released or sold until:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(5)(a): the original motor number, manufacturer's number or identification mark has been replaced; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(5)(b): a new number assigned by the Motor Vehicle Division has been stamped on the vehicle, vessel, or outboard motor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1408(6): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1409 Vehicle immobilization devices -- Definitions -- Notice requirements -- Maximum removal fee.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1409(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1409(1)(a): "Immobilize" means to affix and lock a vehicle immobilization device to the exterior of a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1409(1)(b): "Vehicle immobilization device" means a device that may be affixed and locked to the exterior of a motor vehicle for the purpose of prohibiting the movement or removal of the vehicle from its location.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1409(1)(c): "Vehicle immobilizer" means a person who or entity that uses or causes to be used a vehicle immobilization device for the purpose of enforcing parking restrictions with prior authorization from the owner or person in lawful possession or control of the real property.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501 Motorcycle or motor-driven cycle -- Place for operator to ride -- Passengers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(1): A person operating a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle shall ride only on the permanent and regular seat attached to the motorcycle or motor-driven cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2)(a): (2)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2)(a)(i): a person operating a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle may not carry any other person on the motorcycle or motor-driven cycle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2)(a)(ii): a passenger may not ride on a motorcycle or a motor-driven cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2)(b): If a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle is designed to carry more than one person, a passenger may ride on:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2)(b)(i): the permanent and regular seat, if designed for two persons; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(2)(b)(ii): another seat firmly attached to the motorcycle or motor-driven cycle at the rear or side of the operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(3): A person shall ride on a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle only while sitting astride the seat, facing forward, with one leg on either side of the motorcycle or motor-driven cycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(4): A person may not operate a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle while carrying a package, bundle, or other article which prevents the person from keeping both hands on the handlebars.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(5): An operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle may not carry a person and a person may not ride in a position that interferes with:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(5)(a): the operation or control of the motorcycle or motor-driven cycle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(5)(b): the view of the operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1501(6): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502 Motorcycles, motor-driven cycles, or all-terrain type I vehicles -- Operation on public highways.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(1): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(1)(a): A motorcycle or a motor-driven cycle is entitled to full use of a lane.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(1)(b): An individual may not operate a motor vehicle in a manner that deprives a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle of the full use of a lane.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(1)(c): (1) This Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(2): The operator of a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle may not overtake and pass in the same lane occupied by the vehicle being overtaken.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(3): (3)(b); (3)(a); 41-6a-704
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(3)(a): (3)(b) Except as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(3)(a)(i): lanes of traffic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(3)(a)(ii): adjacent lines or rows of vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(3)(b): (3)(a); 41-6a-704 Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(4): Motorcycles or motor-driven cycles may not be operated more than two abreast in a single lane.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(5): (2); (3)(a) Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(6): The provisions of this section also apply to all-terrain type I vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1502(7): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1503 Motorcycle or motor-driven cycle -- Attaching to another vehicle prohibited.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1503(1): A person riding on a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle may not attach himself to any other vehicle on a roadway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1503(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1504 Motorcycle or motor-driven cycle -- Footrests for passenger -- Height of handlebars limited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1504(1): A motorcycle or motor-driven vehicle carrying a passenger on a public highway, other than in a sidecar or enclosed cab, shall be equipped with footrests for the passenger.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1504(2): A person may not operate a motorcycle or motor-driven cycle with handlebars above shoulder height.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1504(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505 Motorcycle or motor-driven cycle -- Protective headgear -- Closed cab excepted -- Electric assisted bicycles, motor assisted scooters, electric personal assistive mobility devices.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(1): (3) A person under the age of 21 may not operate or ride any of the following on a highway unless the person is wearing protective headgear that complies with specifications adopted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(1)(a): a motorcycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(1)(b): a motor-driven cycle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(1)(c): a class 3 electric assisted bicycle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(1)(d): an autocycle that is not fully enclosed.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(2): This section does not apply to persons riding within an enclosed cab.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(3): The following standards and specifications for protective headgear are adopted:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(3)(a): 49 C.F.R. 571.218 related to protective headgear for motorcycles; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(3)(b): 16 C.F.R. Part 1203 related to protective headgear for bicycles, motor assisted scooters, and electric personal assistive mobility devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(4): (1); (3) A court shall waive $8 of a fine charged to a person operating a vehicle described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(4)(a): 21 years of age or older at the time of operation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(4)(b): (3) wearing protective headgear that complies with the specifications adopted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(5): The failure to wear protective headgear:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(5)(a): does not constitute contributory or comparative negligence on the part of a person seeking recovery for injuries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(5)(b): may not be introduced as evidence in any civil litigation on the issue of negligence, injuries, or the mitigation of damages.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1505(7): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602 Permit to operate vehicle in violation of equipment regulations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602(1): The department may issue a permit which will allow temporary operation of a vehicle in violation of the provisions of this chapter or in violation of rules made by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602(2): The permit shall be carried in the vehicle and shall be displayed upon demand of a magistrate or peace officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602(3)(a): The department may limit the time, manner, or duration of operation and may otherwise prescribe conditions of operation that are necessary to protect the safety of highway users or efficient movement of traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602(3)(b): Any conditions shall be stated on the permit and a person may not violate them.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1602(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603 Lights and illuminating devices -- Duty to display -- Time.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1): (1)(a); (1)(a); 41-6a-1607
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(a): The operator of a vehicle shall ensure the lamps or lights of the vehicle are illuminated while the vehicle is being operated on a highway at any time:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(a)(i): from sunset to sunrise; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(a)(ii): when persons and vehicles on the highway are not clearly discernible at a distance of 1,000 feet ahead  due to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(a)(ii)(A): insufficient light; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(a)(ii)(B): unfavorable atmospheric conditions.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(b)(i): the vehicle's automated light function is operable and engaged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(b)(ii): the automated feature has not been overridden or adjusted.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(1)(c): (1)(a); 41-6a-1607 The lights, lighted lamps, and other lamps and illuminating devices under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(2): (1)(a) Whenever a requirement is made as to distance from which certain lamps and devices shall render objects visible or within which the lamps or devices shall be visible, the provisions apply during the times specified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(3): Whenever a requirement is made as to the mounted height of lamps or devices it shall mean from the center of the lamp or device to the level ground upon which the vehicle stands when the vehicle is without a load.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1603(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1610 Spot lamps.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1610(1): A motor vehicle may not be equipped with more than two spot lamps.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1610(2): A lighted spot lamp may not be aimed or used so that any part of the high intensity portion of the beam strikes the windshield, or any windows, mirror, or occupant of another vehicle in use.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1610(3): This section does not apply to spot lamps on an authorized emergency vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1610(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623 Braking systems required -- Adoption of performance requirements by department.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(1): A motor vehicle and a combination of vehicles shall have a service braking system which will stop the motor vehicle or combination of vehicles within:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(1)(a): 40 feet from an initial speed of 20 miles per hour on a level, dry, smooth, hard surface; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(1)(b): a shorter distance as may be specified by the department in accordance with federal standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(2): A motor vehicle and a combination of vehicles shall have a parking brake system:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(2)(a): adequate to hold the motor vehicle or combination of vehicles on any grade on which it is operated under all conditions of loading on a surface free from snow, ice or loose material; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(2)(b): which complies with performance standards issued by the department in accordance with federal standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(3): (1); (2) In addition to the requirements of Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1623(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1625(3)(a): A vehicle may be equipped with a theft alarm signal device if it is arranged so that it cannot be used by the operator as an ordinary warning signal.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629 Vehicles subject to Sections 41-6a-1629 through 41-6a-1633 -- Definitions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1): 41-6a-1629; 41-6a-1633 As used in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(a): "Frame" means the main longitudinal structural members of the chassis of the vehicle or, for vehicles with unitized body construction, the lowest longitudinal structural member of the body of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(b): "Frame height" means the vertical distance between the ground and the lowest point on the frame.  The distance is measured when the vehicle is unladen and on a level surface.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(c): "Gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR)" means the original manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating, whether or not the vehicle is modified by use of parts not originally installed by the original manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(d): "Manufacturer" means any person engaged in manufacturing or assembling new motor vehicles utilizing new parts or components, or a person defined as a manufacturer in current applicable Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards and Regulations.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(e): "Mechanical alteration" or "mechanical lift" means modification or alteration of the axles, chassis, suspension, or body by any means, including tires and wheels, and excluding any load, which affects the frame height of the motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(f): "O.E.M." means original equipment manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(g): "Original equipment" means an item of motor vehicle equipment, including tires, which were installed in or on a motor vehicle or available as an option for the particular vehicle from the original manufacturer at the time of its delivery to the first purchaser.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(1)(h): "Wheel track" means the shortest distance between the center of the tire treads on the same axle.  On vehicles having dissimilar axle widths, the axle with the widest distance is used for all calculations.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2): (2)(b); (c); 41-6a-1629; 41-6a-1633; 41-6a-1629; 41-6a-1633; 41-6a-1631(2); 41-6a-1632; 41-6a-1633; 41-6a-1509
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(a): (2)(b); (c); 41-6a-1629; 41-6a-1633 Except as provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(b): 41-6a-1629; 41-6a-1633 The provisions of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(b)(i): implements of husbandry;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(b)(ii): farm tractors;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(b)(iii): road machinery;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(b)(iv): road rollers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(b)(v): historical vehicles or horseless carriages that have been restored as near to original condition as is reasonably possible.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1629(2)(c): 41-6a-1631(2); 41-6a-1632; 41-6a-1633; 41-6a-1509 The provisions of Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631 Prohibitions.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1): A person may not operate on a highway a motor vehicle that is mechanically altered or changed:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(a): in any way that may under normal operation:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(a)(i): cause the motor vehicle body or chassis to come in contact with the roadway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(a)(ii): expose the fuel tank to damage from collision; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(a)(iii): cause the wheels to come in contact with the body;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(b): in any manner that may impair the safe operation of the vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(c): so that any part of the vehicle other than tires, rims, and mudguards are less than three inches above the ground;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(d): to a frame height of more than 24 inches for a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of less than 4,500 pounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(e): to a frame height of more than 26 inches for a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of at least 4,500 pounds and less than 7,500 pounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(f): to a frame height of more than 28 inches for a motor vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating of at least 7,500 pounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(g): by stacking or attaching vehicle frames (one from on top of or beneath another frame); or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(1)(h): so that the lowest portion of the body floor is raised more than three inches above the top of the frame.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(2): If the wheel track is increased beyond the O.E.M. specification, the top 50% of the tires shall be covered by the original fenders, by rubber, or other flexible fender extenders under any loading condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1631(3): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632 Bumpers.
-----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(1): A motor vehicle shall be equipped with a bumper on both front and rear of the motor vehicle, except a motor vehicle that was not originally designed or manufactured with a bumper or bumpers.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(2)(a): (1) On a motor vehicle required to have bumpers under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(2)(a)(i): at least 4.5 inches in vertical height;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(2)(a)(ii): centered on the vehicle's center line; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(2)(a)(iii): extend no less than the width of the respective wheel track distance.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(2)(b): A bumper shall be securely mounted, horizontal load bearing, and attached to the motor vehicle's frame to effectively transfer impact when engaged.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(3): If a motor vehicle is originally or later equipped with a bumper, the bumper shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(3)(a): be maintained in operational condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(3)(b): comply with this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1632(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1633 Mudguards or flaps at rear wheels of trucks, trailers, truck tractors, or altered motor vehicles -- Exemptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1633(1): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1633(1)(a): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1633(1)(a)(i): a vehicle that has been altered:

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1633(1)(a)(iv): any trailer or semitrailer with an unladen weight of 750 pounds or more.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1633(2)(b): 41-6a-1507 on a vehicle operated or driven during fair weather on well-maintained, hard-surfaced roads if the motor vehicle:

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1636(1): A solid rubber tire on a vehicle shall have rubber on its entire traction surface at least one inch thick above the edge of the flange of the entire periphery.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1640 Air conditioning equipment -- Requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1640(1): As used in this section, "air conditioning equipment" means mechanical vapor compression refrigeration equipment used to cool the operator or passenger compartment of a motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1640(2): Air conditioning equipment shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1640(2)(a): be manufactured, installed, and maintained with due regard for the safety of the occupants of the vehicle and the public; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1640(2)(b): not contain any refrigerant which is toxic to persons or which is flammable.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1640(3): 41-6a-1601 A person may not have for sale, offer for sale, sell, or equip any motor vehicle with air conditioning equipment unless it complies with the specifications adopted under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645 Advanced driver assistance facilities -- Repair, calibration, and disclosure -- Penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(1): As used in this section, "advanced driver assistance feature" means an electronic safety system that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(1)(a): designed to support the driver and vehicle while operating on roads and highways;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(1)(b): intended to increase vehicle safety and reduce losses associated with automobile crashes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(1)(c): tied to the windshield of a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(2): If a vehicle is equipped with an advanced driver assistance feature, an automotive glass company or repair facility approving or conducting glass repair, replacement, or recalibration on the vehicle shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(2)(a): before approving or performing a vehicle glass repair or replacement, inform the consumer in electronic or hardcopy writing if a recalibration of the advanced driver assistance feature:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(2)(a)(i): is required; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(2)(a)(ii): will be performed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(2)(b): if performing a recalibration of an advanced driver assistance feature, meet or exceed the manufacturer's specifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3): (3)(a)(i); (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(a): (3)(a)(i) The automotive glass company or repair facility shall provide the consumer:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(a)(i): an itemized description of the work to be done on the vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(i) if an insurer is paying all or part of the repair, the total amount the insurer has agreed to pay for the work described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(b): (3)(a) An insurance company that pays for work described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(c): An automotive glass company or repair facility may not represent to a customer that the cost of a repair, replacement, or recalibration will be paid for entirely by the customer's insurer and at no cost to the customer unless the cost of the repair, replacement, or recalibration is fully covered and approved by the insurer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(d): If a recalibration was not performed or not completed successfully, the automotive glass company or repair facility shall inform the consumer electronically or in writing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(d)(i): the recalibration was not successful or was not performed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(3)(d)(ii): the vehicle should be taken to a vehicle manufacturer's certified dealership, a qualified automobile glass company, or repair facility capable of performing the recalibration of an advanced driver assistance feature that meets or exceeds the manufacturer's specifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(4): An automotive glass company or repair facility conducting a scan or recalibration for vehicle glass repair or replacement services on a vehicle equipped with an advanced driver assistance feature:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(4)(a): is not limited to vehicle glass, tooling, or equipment dictated or recommended by the manufacturer's procedures or specifications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(4)(b): shall recalibrate the advanced driver assistance feature to meet or exceed the manufacturer's procedures or specifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1645(5): An automotive glass company or repair facility may only bill or charge for vehicle glass repair, replacement, or recalibration services that are performed and necessary.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646 Motor vehicle glass repair requirements -- Penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(1): (1)(a) An automotive glass company or repair facility shall provide a consumer seeking motor vehicle glass repair or replacement:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(1)(a): an electronic or hardcopy written and itemized description of the work to be done on the vehicle; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(1)(b): (1)(a) if an insurer is paying all or part of the repair, the total amount the insurer has agreed to pay for the work described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(2): (1)(a) An insurance company that pays for work described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(3): An automotive glass company or repair facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(3)(a): may not represent to a customer that the cost of a repair or replacement will be paid for entirely by the customer's insurer and at no cost to the customer unless the cost of the repair or replacement is fully covered and approved by the insurer;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(3)(b): is not limited to vehicle glass, tooling, or equipment dictated or recommended by the manufacturer's procedures or specifications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(3)(c): may only bill or charge for vehicle glass repair, replacement, or recalibration services that are performed and necessary.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(4)(a): guilty of an infraction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1646(4)(b): subject to a civil penalty of $500.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1701 Backing -- When permissible.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1701(1): The operator of a vehicle may not back the vehicle unless the movement can be made with safety and without interfering with other traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1701(2): The operator of a vehicle may not back the vehicle on a shoulder or roadway of a limited-access roadway.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1702 Sidewalk -- Driving prohibited -- Exception.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1702(1): 41-6a-1115.1(3) Except for a bicycle, a device propelled by human power, or a motor assisted scooter, a person may not operate a vehicle on a sidewalk or sidewalk area. A motor assisted scooter may be operated on a sidewalk only if permitted pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1702(2): (1) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1703 Prohibition as to passenger riding on improper portion of motor vehicle -- Exceptions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1703(1): A person may not ride and a person operating a motor vehicle may not knowingly permit a person to ride on any portion of a vehicle not designed or intended for the use of passengers.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1703(2): This provision does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1703(2)(a): a vehicle that is not being operated on a highway;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1703(2)(b): an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of the employee's duty; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1703(2)(c): a person riding within or on a motor vehicle in a space intended for a load on the vehicle.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1704 Vehicle door -- Prohibited opening.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1704(1): A person may not open the door of a motor vehicle on a side available to moving traffic unless it can be done safely and without interfering with the movement of other traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1704(2): A person may not leave a door open on a side of a vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705 Obstruction to driver's view or driving mechanism.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705(1): A person may not operate a vehicle when it is loaded or when there are in the front seat more than three persons that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705(1)(a): obstruct the view of the operator to the front or sides of the vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705(1)(b): interfere with the operator's control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705(2): A passenger in a vehicle may not ride in a position that interferes with the operator's:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705(2)(a): view ahead or to the sides; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1705(2)(b): control over the driving mechanism of the vehicle.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1706 Occupancy of a trailer or semitrailer while being moved on highway prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1706(1): A person may not occupy a trailer or semitrailer while it is being drawn by a motor vehicle on a public highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1706(2): This section does not apply to a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1706(2)(a): livestock trailer or livestock semitrailer;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1706(2)(b): trailer or semitrailer being used for participation in a parade; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1706(2)(c): trailer or semitrailer being used in an agricultural operation.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1707 Entering intersection, crosswalk, or railroad grade -- Sufficient space required.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The operator of a vehicle may not enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk or drive onto any railroad grade crossing unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection, crosswalk, or railroad grade crossing to accommodate the vehicle without obstructing the passage of other vehicles, pedestrians, or railroad trains notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1710 Following near an authorized emergency vehicle or parking near fire apparatus prohibited.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Except for a person operating an authorized emergency vehicle, the operator of a vehicle may not:Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1710(1): follow closer than 500 feet any authorized emergency vehicle traveling in response to an emergency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1710(2): stop the vehicle within 500 feet of a fire apparatus which has stopped in answer to a fire alarm.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1711 Driving over firehose.
-------------------------------------------------------
The operator of a vehicle may not drive over an unprotected hose of a fire department when laid down on a street, private road, or driveway to be used at a fire or alarm of fire, without the consent of the fire department official in command.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712 Destructive or injurious materials on highways -- Throwing lighted material from moving vehicle -- Enforcement officers.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(1): A person may not throw, deposit, or discard, or permit to be dropped, thrown, deposited, or discarded on any public road or highway in the state, whether under state, county, municipal, or federal ownership, any plastic container, glass bottle, glass, nails, tacks, wire, cans, barbed wire, boards, trash or garbage, paper or paper products, or any other substance which would or could:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(1)(a): create a safety or health hazard on the public road or highway; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(1)(b): mar or impair the scenic aspect or beauty of the public road or highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(2): A person who drops, throws, deposits, or discards, or permits to be dropped, thrown, deposited, or discarded, on any public road or highway any destructive, injurious, or unsightly material shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(2)(a): immediately remove the material or cause it to be removed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(2)(b): deposit the material in a receptacle designed to receive the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(3): A person distributing commercial handbills, leaflets, or other advertising shall take whatever measures are reasonably necessary to keep the material from littering public roadways or highways.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(4): A person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a public road or highway shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped from the vehicle on the road or highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(5): A person may not throw any lighted material from a moving vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(6): 72-7-409 Except as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(7): 53-13-103 A law enforcement officer as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(7)(a): shall enforce the provisions of this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(7)(b): may issue citations to a person who violates any of the provisions of this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(7)(c): may serve and execute all warrants, citations, and other process issued by any court in enforcing this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1712(8): A municipality within its corporate limits and a county outside of incorporated municipalities may enact local ordinances to carry out the provisions of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713 Penalty for littering on a highway.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713(1): 41-6a-1712 A person who violates any of the provisions of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713(1)(a): not less than $200 for a violation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713(1)(b): not less than $500 for a second or subsequent violation within three years of a previous violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713(2): The sentencing judge may require that the offender devote at least eight hours in cleaning up:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713(2)(a): litter caused by the offender; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1713(2)(b): existing litter from a safe area designated by the sentencing judge.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1714 Warning signs.
-----------------------------------------------
The Department of Transportation shall place adequate warning signs wherever it considers proper within the state notifying all persons using the public roads, highways, parks, or recreation areas of the provisions of Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715 Careless driving defined and prohibited.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(1): Part 6, Speed Restrictions A person operating a motor vehicle is guilty of careless driving if the person:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(1)(a): commits two or more moving traffic violations under this chapter in a series of acts within a single continuous period of driving covering three miles or less in total distance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(1)(b): Part 6, Speed Restrictions commits a moving traffic violation under this chapter other than a moving traffic violation under
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(1)(b)(i): searching for an item in the vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(1)(b)(ii): attending to personal hygiene or grooming.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(2): A violation of this section is a class C misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1715(3): 53-3-218(7) In addition to the penalty provided under this section or any other section, a judge may order the revocation of the convicted person's driver license if the violation causes or results in the death of another person in accordance with Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(3)(d): when reporting a safety hazard or requesting assistance relating to a safety hazard;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(3)(e): when reporting criminal activity or requesting assistance relating to a criminal activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(3)(f): when used by a law enforcement officer or emergency service personnel acting within the course and scope of the law enforcement officer's or emergency service personnel's employment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(3)(g): to operate:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(3)(g)(i): hands-free or voice operated technology; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(3)(g)(ii): a system that is physically or electronically integrated into the motor vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4): An individual convicted of a violation of this section is guilty of a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4)(a): class C misdemeanor with a maximum fine of $100; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4)(b): class B misdemeanor if the individual:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4)(b)(i): has also inflicted serious bodily injury upon another as a proximate result of using a wireless communication device in violation of this section while operating a moving motor vehicle on a highway in this state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4)(b)(ii): has a prior conviction under this section, that is within three years of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4)(b)(ii)(A): the current conviction under this section; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1716(4)(b)(ii)(B): the commission of the offense upon which the current conviction is based.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804 Exceptions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804(1): This part does not apply to an operator or passenger of:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804(1)(a): a motor vehicle manufactured before July 1, 1966;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804(1)(b): a motor vehicle in which the operator or passengers possess a written verification from a licensed physician or physician assistant that the person is unable to wear a safety belt for physical or medical reasons; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804(1)(c): a motor vehicle or seating position which is not required to be equipped with a safety belt system under federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804(2): This part does not apply to a passenger if all seating positions are occupied by other passengers.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1804(3): This part does not apply to a passenger of a public transit vehicle with a gross vehicle weight rating exceeding 10,000 pounds.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1806 Compliance -- Civil litigation.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The failure to use a child restraint device or to wear a safety belt:Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1806(1): does not constitute contributory or comparative negligence on the part of a person seeking recovery for injuries; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-1806(2): may not be introduced as evidence in any civil litigation on the issue of negligence, injuries, or the mitigation of damages.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2001 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Automatic License Plate Reader System Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(1): "Automatic license plate reader system" means a system of one or more mobile or fixed automated high-speed cameras used in combination with computer algorithms to convert an image of a license plate into computer-readable data.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(2): "Captured plate data" means the global positioning system coordinates, date and time, photograph, license plate number, and any other data captured by or derived from an automatic license plate reader system.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3): (3)(a)(i); (xviii)

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(iii): the Board of Pardons and Parole;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(iv): the Board of Examiners;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(v): the National Guard;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(vi): the Career Service Review Office;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(vii): the State Board of Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(viii): the Utah Board of Higher Education;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(ix): the State Archives;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(x): the Office of the Legislative Auditor General;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(xi): the Office of the Legislative Fiscal Analyst;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(xiii): the Legislature;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(xv): courts, the Judicial Council, the Administrative Office of the Courts, and similar administrative units in the judicial branch;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(3)(a)(xvi): any state-funded institution of higher education or public education;

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(4): "Nongovernmental entity" means a person that is not a governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2002(5): "Secured area" means an area, enclosed by clear boundaries, to which access is limited and not open to the public and entry is only obtainable through specific access-control points.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005 Preservation request.
------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1): A person or governmental entity using an automatic license plate reader system shall take all steps necessary to preserve captured plate data in its possession for 14 days after the date the data is captured pending the issuance of a court order requiring the disclosure of the captured plate data if a governmental entity or defendant in a criminal case requesting the captured plate data submits a written statement to the person or governmental entity using an automatic license plate reader system:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1)(a): requesting the person or governmental entity to preserve the captured plate data;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1)(b): identifying:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1)(b)(i): the camera or cameras for which captured plate data shall be preserved;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1)(b)(ii): the license plate for which captured plate data shall be preserved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1)(b)(iii): the dates and time frames for which captured plate data shall be preserved; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(1)(c): notifying the person or governmental entity maintaining the captured plate data that the governmental entity or defendant in a criminal case is applying for a court order for disclosure of the captured plate data.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(2)(a): A governmental entity or defendant in a criminal case may apply for a court order for the disclosure of captured plate data possessed by a governmental entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-6a-2005(2)(b): A court that is a court of competent jurisdiction shall issue a court order requiring the disclosure of captured plate data if the governmental entity or defendant in a criminal case offers specific and articulable facts showing that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the captured plate data is relevant and material to an ongoing criminal or missing person investigation.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-103(2)(b)(i): arising out of the ownership, maintenance, or use of any motor vehicle, including damages for care and loss of services because of bodily injury to or death of any person, or because of injury to or destruction of property including the loss of use of the property; or

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-103(4)(b): "Motor vehicle" does not include traction engines, road rollers, farm tractors, tractor cranes, power shovels, and well drillers, and every vehicle that is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead wires but not operated upon rails.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-103(5): "Nonresident" means every person who is not a resident of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-103(8)(d): a mortgagor if a motor vehicle is the subject of a mortgage with the mortgagor entitled to possession.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-104 Rules of construction.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-104(1): If a person maintains owner's security under this chapter, it does not limit his liability to the face amount of the owner's security.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-104(2): Nothing in this chapter prevents the plaintiff in any action at law from relying for relief upon the other processes provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-104(3): This chapter is cumulative with the requirements of the laws of this state requiring policies of motor vehicle insurance against liability.   This subsection does not preclude compliance through a single policy which, by its terms or by an appropriate endorsement, satisfies the requirements of both applicable laws.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-408 Substitution of forms of proof of owner's or operator's security.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall consent to the cancellation of any bond or certificate of insurance or the department shall direct and the state treasurer shall return any money or securities to the person entitled to them upon the substitution and acceptance of other adequate proof of owner's or operator's security in a manner allowed under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-409 Power to require proof of owner's or operator's security in other form.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If, after a hearing, the department determines that a particular proof of owner's or operator's security filed under this chapter no longer fulfills the purposes for which it is required, the department shall require proof of security in another permitted form.  Pending the filing of the other proof, the department shall suspend the license and registration or the nonresident's operating privilege.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-410 Employee and family relationships.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Whenever any person required to give proof of owner's or operator's security is an operator in the employ of any owner, or is a member of the immediate family or household of the owner, the department shall accept proof of security by the owner in lieu of proof by the employee, family, or household member.  The department shall indicate by restriction on the operator's license the vehicles the operator may operate on the basis of that proof of security.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-504 Payments by insurers as evidence to the department.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-504(1): The department may accept evidence of a payment to an operator or owner of a motor vehicle involved in an accident by the insurer of any other person involved in the accident on account of damage to property as effective to relieve the operator from the post-accident security and suspension provisions of this chapter in respect to any claim for property damage by the person on whose behalf the payment has been made.  A payment to the insurer of an operator or owner under its right of subrogation is the equivalent of a payment to the operator or owner.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-504(2): The department may accept evidence of a payment on account of bodily injury to a person involved in an accident by the insurer of any other person involved in the accident as effective to relieve the person to whom the payment is made from the post-accident security and suspension provisions of this chapter in respect to any claim for bodily injury by the person on whose behalf the payment is made.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-506 Application to persons without license or registration.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the operator or the owner of a motor vehicle involved in an accident in Utah has no license or registration in Utah, or is a nonresident, he may not obtain a license or registration in Utah until he has complied with the requirements of this chapter to the extent that would be necessary if, at the time of the accident, he held a Utah license and registration.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-507 Cooperation with other states.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-507(1): (2) When a nonresident's operating privilege is suspended under this chapter, the department shall send a certified copy of the record of the action to the official in charge of the issuance of licenses and registration certificates in the state in which the nonresident resides, if the law of the other state provides for action similar to that provided for in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-507(2): Upon receipt of certification from the official of another state that the operating privilege of a Utah resident has been suspended in the other state for failure to deposit post-accident security for the payment of judgments arising out of a motor vehicle accident, under circumstances which would require the deposit in Utah, the department shall suspend the license of the resident if he was the operator, and all of his registrations if he was the owner of a motor vehicle involved in the accident.  These suspensions continue until the Utah resident furnishes evidence of his compliance with the law of the other state relating to the deposit of post-accident security.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-601 Collusive transfers prohibited.
----------------------------------------------------------------
If an owner's registration has been suspended under this chapter, the registration may not be transferred nor the motor vehicle registered in any other name until the department is satisfied that the transfer or registration is proposed in good faith and not with the intent or the effect of defeating the purposes of this chapter.  This section does not affect the rights of a conditional vendor, chattel mortgagee, or lessor of a motor vehicle registered in the name of another as owner who becomes subject to the provisions of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-602 Filing of false report.
--------------------------------------------------------
Any person who gives information required in a report provided for under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-603 Operating motor vehicle without license or registration.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person whose license or registration or nonresident's operating privilege has been suspended or revoked under this chapter and who, during the suspension or revocation drives any motor vehicle upon any highway or knowingly permits any motor vehicle owned by the person to be operated by another upon any highway, except as permitted under this chapter, is guilty of a class  C misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-604 Suspension of license.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-604(1): A person convicted of a class A or a class B misdemeanor under this chapter, in addition to any other penalties which are imposed by law, shall have his operator's license suspended by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-604(2): Whenever any person is convicted of an offense for which this chapter mandates the suspension of his license or the registration of his motor vehicle, and that person does not produce proof of owner's or operator's security at the time of his appearance, the court in which the conviction takes place shall require the surrender to it of all pertinent evidences of registration, including all registration cards, license plates, nonresident temporary permits, and other similar materials then held by the person so convicted.  This court shall then forward the registration materials to the Motor Vehicle Division of the State Tax Commission and send the Driver License Division a record of the conviction.  If the person so convicted secures a judgment of acquittal or reversal of this conviction in any appellate court, the department shall reinstate his driver license or privilege and the Motor Vehicle Division shall reinstate the registration of his motor vehicle immediately upon receipt of a certified copy of the judgment of acquittal or reversal.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-604(3): If the owner has surrendered the owner's registration materials to the Motor Vehicle Division, the owner may, unless otherwise prohibited by law, apply for a new registration, by providing proof of owner's security.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-605 Other violations.
--------------------------------------------------
Any person who violates any provision of this chapter for which no penalty is otherwise provided is guilty of a class C misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-606 Authority of political subdivisions to adopt ordinances.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter shall be applied uniformly throughout the state and in all municipalities and other political subdivisions.  Local authorities may, however, adopt regulations or ordinances consistent with this chapter and additional traffic regulations which are not in conflict with this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-12a-801 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Uninsured Motorist Identification Database Program."

Utah Code Annotated - Title 41 - Chapter 19 - Federal Highway Safety Act
************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 41-19-1 Powers and duties of governor.
------------------------------------------------------------
The governor, in addition to other duties and responsibilities conferred upon him by the Constitution and laws of the state of Utah is hereby empowered to contract and to do all other things necessary in behalf of the state to secure the full benefits available to this state under the federal Highway Safety Act of 1966, and any amendments thereto, and in so doing, to cooperate with the federal and state agencies, agencies private and public, interested organizations, and with individuals, to effectuate the purposes of that enactment, and any and all subsequent amendments thereto. The governor shall be the official having the ultimate responsibility for dealing with the United States Government with respect to programs and activities pursuant to the federal Highway Safety Act of 1966, and any amendments thereto. To that end he shall be responsible for activities of any and all departments and agencies of this state and its subdivisions, relating thereto. He may designate an appropriate person, commission or board to assist him in coordinating the activities and programs contemplated under this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-19-2 Participation by political subdivisions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
The Legislature of the state of Utah hereby authorizes the political subdivisions of this state to participate in the state highway safety program as contemplated by the federal Highway Safety Act of 1966, and any amendments thereto, and to do all things necessary to secure benefits available under that act.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-21-3 Minimum speed inapplicable.
---------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this title relating to minimum speed provisions upon highways do not apply to vehicles properly registered under

Utah Code Annotated § 41-21-4 Minimum safety equipment inapplicable.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this title relating to minimum safety equipment are not applicable to vehicles properly registered under

Utah Code Annotated § 41-21-5 Operation on public highways.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Any motor vehicle properly registered under this chapter may be operated or moved on the streets and highways for going to or from an assembly, convention, parade, or other meeting where the vehicles and their ownership are of primary interest, or while they are being driven to or from, or while on local, state, or national tours held primarily for the exhibition and enjoyment of the vehicles by their owners, and so long as the vehicle or group of vehicles are not operated in a manner which would constitute a public nuisance or create a hazard to other automobiles or persons.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-21-6 Revocation of registration -- Powers of tax commission.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The tax commission may revoke the registration of a vintage vehicle for failure to comply with this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 41 - Chapter 22 - Off-highway Vehicles
******************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-1 Policy declaration.
-------------------------------------------------
It is the policy of this state to promote safety and protection for persons, property, and the environment connected with the use, operation, and equipment of off-highway vehicles, to promote uniformity of laws, to adopt and pursue a safety education program, and to develop trails and other facilities for the use of these vehicles.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2 Definitions.
------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(1): "Advisory council" means an advisory council appointed by the Division of Outdoor Recreation that has within the advisory council's duties advising on policies related to the use of off-highway vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(2): "All-terrain type I vehicle" means any motor vehicle 52 inches or less in width, having an unladen dry weight of 1,500 pounds or less, traveling on three or more low pressure tires, having a seat designed to be straddled by the operator, and designed for or capable of travel over unimproved terrain.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(3): 41-1a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(3)(a): "All-terrain type II vehicle" means any motor vehicle 80 inches or less in width, traveling on four or more low pressure tires, having a steering wheel, non-straddle seating, a rollover protection system, and designed for or capable of travel over unimproved terrain, and is:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(3)(a)(i): an electric-powered vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(3)(a)(ii): a vehicle powered by an internal combustion engine and has an unladen dry weight of 3,500 pounds or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(3)(b): 41-1a-102 "All-terrain type II vehicle" does not include golf carts, any vehicle designed to carry a person with a disability, any vehicle not specifically designed for recreational use, or farm tractors as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(4): (2); (3); (12); (22); 41-1a-102
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(4)(a): (2); (3); (12); (22) "All-terrain type III vehicle" means any other motor vehicle, not defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(4)(b): 41-1a-102 "All-terrain type III vehicle" does not include golf carts, any vehicle designed to carry a person with a disability, any vehicle not specifically designed for recreational use, or farm tractors as defined under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(5): "Commission" means the Outdoor Adventure Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(6): "Cross-country" means across natural terrain and off an existing highway, road, route, or trail.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(7): "Dealer" means a person engaged in the business of selling off-highway vehicles at wholesale or retail.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(8): "Division" means the Division of Outdoor Recreation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(9): "Low pressure tire" means any pneumatic tire six inches or more in width designed for use on wheels with rim diameter of 14 inches or less and utilizing an operating pressure of 10 pounds per square inch or less as recommended by the vehicle manufacturer.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(10): "Manufacturer" means a person engaged in the business of manufacturing off-highway vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(11)(a): "Motor vehicle" means every vehicle which is self-propelled.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(11)(b): "Motor vehicle" includes an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(12): "Motorcycle" means every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the operator and designed to travel on not more than two tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(13): "Off-highway implement of husbandry" means every all-terrain type I vehicle,  all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle,  motorcycle, or snowmobile that is used by the owner or the owner's agent for agricultural operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(14): "Off-highway vehicle" means any snowmobile, all-terrain type I vehicle, all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle, or motorcycle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(15): "Operate" means to control the movement of or otherwise use an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(16): "Operator" means the person who is in actual physical control of an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(17): Title 16, Chapter 6a, Utah Revised Nonprofit Corporation Act "Organized user group" means an off-highway vehicle organization incorporated as a nonprofit corporation in the state under
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(18): "Owner" means a person, other than a person with a security interest, having a property interest or title to an off-highway vehicle and entitled to the use and possession of that vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(19): "Public land" means land owned or administered by any federal or state agency or any political subdivision of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(20): "Register" means the act of assigning a registration number to an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(21): 41-6a-102 "Roadway" is used as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(22): "Snowmobile" means any motor vehicle designed for travel on snow or ice and steered and supported in whole or in part by skis, belts, cleats, runners, or low pressure tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(23): "Street or highway" means the entire width between boundary lines of every way or place of whatever nature, when any part of it is open to the use of the public for vehicular travel.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-2(24): 41-6a-102 "Street-legal all-terrain vehicle" or "street-legal ATV" has the same meaning as defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4 Falsification of documents unlawful -- Alteration or removal of serial number unlawful -- Display of sticker.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4(1): A person may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4(1)(a): knowingly falsify an application for registration, affidavit of ownership, or bill of sale for any off-highway vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4(1)(b): alter, deface, or remove any manufacturer's serial number on any off-highway vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4(1)(c): use or permit the use or display of any registration sticker, registration card, or permit upon an off-highway vehicle or in the operation of any off-highway vehicle other than the vehicle for which it was issued; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4(1)(d): alter or deface a registration sticker, registration card, or permit issued to an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-4(2): A violation of this section is a class C misdemeanor.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5 Off-highway husbandry vehicles.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1): (1)(a)(i); (1); 41-22-3
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(a): (1)(a)(i); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(a)(i): The owner of an all-terrain type I vehicle, motorcycle, all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle, or snowmobile used for agricultural purposes may apply to the Motor Vehicle Division for an off-highway implement of husbandry sticker.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(a)(ii): (1)(a)(i) Each application under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(a)(ii)(A): evidence of ownership;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(a)(ii)(B): a title or a manufacturer's certificate of origin; and

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(b): 41-22-3 If the vehicle is also used for recreational purposes on public lands, trails, streets, or highways, it shall also be registered under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(1)(c): The off-highway implement of husbandry sticker shall be displayed in a manner prescribed by the division and shall identify the all-terrain type I vehicle, motorcycle, all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle, or snowmobile as an off-highway implement of husbandry.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(2): The off-highway implement of husbandry sticker is valid only for the life of the ownership of the all-terrain type I vehicle, motorcycle, all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle, or snowmobile and is not transferable.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(3): The off-highway implement of husbandry sticker is valid for an all-terrain type I vehicle, motorcycle, all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle, or snowmobile that is being operated adjacent to a roadway:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(3)(a): when the all-terrain type I vehicle, motorcycle, all-terrain type II vehicle, all-terrain type III vehicle, or snowmobile is only being used to travel from one parcel of land owned, operated, permitted, or leased for agricultural purposes by the owner of the vehicle to another parcel of land owned, operated, permitted, or leased for agricultural purposes by the owner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(3)(b): when this operation is necessary for the furtherance of agricultural purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(4): If the operation of an off-highway implement of husbandry adjacent to a roadway is impractical, it may be operated on the roadway if the operator exercises due care towards conventional motor vehicle traffic.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(5): It is unlawful to operate an off-highway implement of husbandry along, across, or within the boundaries of an interstate freeway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-5.5(6): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-7 Duplicate registration cards and registration stickers.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-7(1): If a registration card is lost or destroyed, or if an owner changes the owner's address from the address shown on the owner's registration card, the owner shall, within 15 days, apply for a duplicate registration card.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-7(2): If a registration sticker is lost, stolen, or becomes illegible, the owner of the off-highway vehicle shall immediately apply for and obtain a replacement registration sticker.
