Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10 Powers of division relating to off-highway vehicles.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The division may:Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10(1): appoint and seek recommendations from the advisory council representing the various off-highway vehicle, conservation, and other appropriate interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10(2): adopt a uniform marker and sign system for use by agents of appropriate federal, state, county, and city agencies in areas of off-highway vehicle use.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1 Vehicles operated on posted public land.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1(1): Currently registered off-highway vehicles may be operated on public land, trails, streets, or highways that are posted by sign or designated by map or description as open to off-highway vehicle use by the controlling federal, state, county, or municipal agency.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1(2): The controlling federal, state, county, or municipal agency may:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1(2)(a): provide a map or description showing or describing land, trails, streets, or highways open to off-highway vehicle use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1(2)(b): post signs designating lands, trails, streets, or highways open to off-highway vehicle use.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1(3): Liability may not be imposed on any federal, state, county, or municipality relating to the designation or maintenance of any land, trail, street, or highway open for off-highway vehicle use.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.1(4): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.2 Off-highway vehicles -- Prohibited on interstate freeway.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.2(1): 41-6a-102 It is unlawful for an off-highway vehicle to operate along, across, or within the boundaries of an interstate freeway, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.2(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.3 Operation of vehicles on highways -- Limits.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A person may not operate an off-highway vehicle upon any street or highway, not designated as open to off-highway vehicle use, except:Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.3(1): when crossing a street or highway and the operator comes to a complete stop before crossing, proceeds only after yielding the right of way to oncoming traffic, and crosses at a right angle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.3(2): when loading or unloading an off-highway vehicle from a vehicle or trailer, which shall be done with due regard for safety, and at the nearest practical point of operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.3(3): when an emergency exists, during any period of time and at those locations when the operation of conventional motor vehicles is impractical or when the operation is directed by a peace officer or other public authority; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.3(4): 41-6a-1509 when operating a street-legal all-terrain vehicle on a highway in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.3(5): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.4 Snowmobiles.
---------------------------------------------
Snowmobiles may be operated on streets or highways which have been officially closed for the season to conventional motor vehicle traffic because snow removal is no longer provided for the season by the public authority having jurisdiction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.8 Protective headgear requirements -- Owner duty -- Penalty for violation.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.8(1): A person under the age of 18 may not operate or ride on all-terrain type I vehicles, snowmobiles, or motorcycles on public land unless the person is wearing a properly fitted and fastened, United States Department of Transportation safety-rated protective headgear designed for motorized vehicle use.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-10.8(5)(a): 18 years of age or older at the time of operation; and

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-11 Agencies authorized to erect regulatory signs on public land.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-11(1): No person, except an agent of an appropriate federal, state, county, or city agency, operating within that agency's authority, may place a regulatory sign governing off-highway vehicle use on any public land.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-11(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12 Restrictions on use of public lands.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12(1): 79-4-203; 79-4-304 Except as provided in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.1 Restrictions on use of snowmobile trails.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.1(1): A person may not operate a wheeled vehicle with a gross vehicle weight of 800 pounds or more on any snowmobile trail that the division has marked, posted, designated, or maintained as a snowmobile trail.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.1(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.8 Exceptions to off-highway vehicle use restrictions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The cross-country motor vehicle and off-highway vehicle restrictions in SectionsUtah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.8(1): a law enforcement officer or emergency services personnel acting within the course and scope of their employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.8(2): an employee of the landowner or land manager acting within the course and scope of their employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.8(3): a person otherwise authorized to use a motor vehicle in a closed area by legal right or by permission of the landowner or land manager; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-12.8(4): a person operating a motor vehicle on an R.S. 2477 right-of-way recorded or asserted by the state or a local highway authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-13 Prohibited uses.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-13(1): No person may operate an off-highway vehicle in connection with acts of vandalism, harassment of wildlife or domestic animals, burglaries or other crimes, or damage to the environment which includes excessive pollution of air, water, or land, abuse of the watershed, impairment of plant or animal life, or excessive mechanical noise.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-13(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-15 Permission required for race or organized event.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-15(1): No person may organize, promote, or hold an off-highway vehicle race or other organized event on any land or highway within this state, except as permitted by the appropriate agency or landowner having jurisdiction over the land or highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-15(2): A violation of this section is an infraction.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-17 Penalties for violations.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-17(1): Except as otherwise provided, a person who violates the provisions of this chapter is guilty of an infraction.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-17(2): The division may revoke or suspend the registration of any off-highway vehicle whose application for registration has been falsified.  The owner shall surrender to the division, within 15 days of suspension or revocation, the suspended or revoked registration card and registration sticker.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-18 Ordinances or local laws relating to operation and equipment of vehicles.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The provisions of this chapter and other applicable laws of this state govern the operation, equipment, registration, and all other matters relating to the use of off-highway vehicles on public land.  Nothing in this chapter may be construed to prevent the adoption of any ordinance or local law relating to the operation and equipment of off-highway vehicles in which the provisions are identical to the provisions of this chapter or the rules promulgated under this chapter, but these ordinances or local laws shall be operative only as long as and to the extent that they continue to be identical to the provisions of this chapter or the rules promulgated under this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-20 Public land administrating agencies to develop facilities and programs.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
All public land administering agencies are encouraged:Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-20(1): to develop and maintain trails, parking areas, rest rooms, and other related facilities appropriate to off-highway vehicle use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-20(2): to promote the safety, enjoyment, and responsible use of all forms of this recreational activity.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-21 Publication of rules and amendments.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The rules promulgated under this chapter and any amendments to those rules shall be published as required by the Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37 Off-highway vehicle operator responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(1): An off-highway vehicle operator who is 18 years of age or older shall accept legal responsibility for injury or damage of any kind to the extent that the injury or damage results from risks inherent in the sport of off-highway vehicle use.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(a): An off-highway vehicle operator shall regulate personal conduct at all times so that injury to self or other persons or property that results from the risks inherent in the sport of off-highway vehicle operation is avoided.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b): (1) Risks inherent in the sport of off-highway vehicle operation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(i): variations in terrain;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(ii): surface or subsurface conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(iii): crevices;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(iv): ravines;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(v): streams;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(vi): poor visibility;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(vii): rocks;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(viii): trees;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(ix): other forms of forest growth or debris; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(2)(b)(x): any other natural hazard.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(3): An off-highway vehicle operator is responsible for:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(3)(a): knowing the range of the operator's ability to navigate any slope, trail, or area for off-highway vehicle use, taking into consideration the conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(3)(b): maintaining control of speed and course at all times while operating the off-highway vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(3)(c): heeding all posted warnings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(3)(d): refraining from acting in a manner that may cause or contribute to the injury of any person.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(4): The provisions of this section do not affect a product liability cause of action based upon proper warning, design, or manufacture of off-highway equipment or products or safety equipment used incidental to the operation of an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(5): The provisions of this section do not affect a passenger's cause of action or ability to recover for injuries.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-22-37(6): The provisions of this section do not affect an off-highway vehicle owner's liability for negligent entrustment.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 41 - Chapter 26 - Autonomous Vehicles
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Autonomous Vehicles."

Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(1): "ADS-dedicated vehicle" means a vehicle designed to be operated exclusively by a level four or five ADS for all trips within the given operational design domain limitations of the ADS, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(2)(a): "Automated driving system" or "ADS" means the hardware and software that are collectively capable of performing the entire dynamic driving task on a sustained basis, regardless of whether the ADS is limited to a specific operational design domain, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(2)(b): "Automated driving system" or "ADS" is used specifically to describe a level three, four, or five driving automation system.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(3): 59-1-101 "Commission" means the State Tax Commission as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(4): "Conventional driver" means a human driver who is onboard the motor vehicle and manually performs some or all of the following actions in order to operate a vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(4)(a): braking;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(4)(b): accelerating;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(4)(c): steering; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(4)(d): transmission gear selection input devices.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(5)(a): "Dispatch" means to place an ADS-equipped vehicle into service in driverless operation by engaging the ADS.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(5)(b): "Dispatch" includes software-enabled dispatch of multiple ADS-equipped motor vehicles in driverless operation that may complete multiple trips involving pick-up and drop-off of passengers or goods throughout a day or other pre-defined periods of service, and which may involve multiple agents performing various tasks related to the dispatch function.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(6): 41-1a-106 "Division" means the Motor Vehicle Division of the commission, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(7): "Driverless operation" means the operation of an ADS-equipped vehicle in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(7)(a): no on-board user is present; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(7)(b): no on-board user is a human driver with a valid driver license or fallback-ready user.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(8): "Driverless operation dispatcher" means a user who dispatches an ADS-equipped vehicle in driverless operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(9): "Driving automation system" means the hardware and software collectively capable of performing part or all of the dynamic driving task on a sustained basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(10): "Driving automation system feature" means a specific function of a driving automation system.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a): "Dynamic driving task" means all of the real-time operational and tactical functions required to operate a motor vehicle in on-road traffic, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a)(i): lateral vehicle motion control through steering;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a)(ii): longitudinal motion control through acceleration and deceleration;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a)(iii): monitoring the driving environment through object and event detection, recognition, classification, and response preparation;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a)(iv): object and event response execution;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a)(v): maneuver planning; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(a)(vi): enhancing conspicuity with lighting, signaling, and gesturing.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(11)(b): "Dynamic driving task" does not include strategic functions such as trip scheduling and selection of destinations and waypoints.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(12): "Engage" as it pertains to the operation of a vehicle by a driving automation system means to cause a driving automation system feature to perform part or all of the dynamic driving task on a sustained basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(13): "External event" is a situation in the driving environment that necessitates a response by a human driver with a valid driver license or driving automation system.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(14): "Fallback-ready user" means the user of a vehicle equipped with an engaged level three ADS who is:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(14)(a): a human driver with a valid driver license; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(14)(b): ready to operate the vehicle if:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(14)(b)(i): a system failure occurs; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(14)(b)(ii): the ADS issues a request to intervene.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(15)(a): "Human driver" means a natural person who performs in real-time all or part of the dynamic driving task.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(15)(b): "Human driver" includes a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(15)(b)(i): conventional driver; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(15)(b)(ii): remote driver.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(16): "Level five automated driving system" or "level five ADS" means an ADS feature that has the capability to perform on a sustained basis the entire dynamic driving task under all conditions that can reasonably be managed by a human driver, as well as any maneuvers necessary to respond to a system failure, without any expectation that a human user will respond to a request to intervene.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(17): "Level four automated driving system" or "level four ADS" means an ADS feature that, without any expectation that a human user will respond to a request to intervene, has:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(17)(a): the capability to perform on a sustained basis the entire dynamic driving task within its operational design domain; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(17)(b): the capability to perform any maneuvers necessary to achieve a minimal risk condition in response to:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(17)(b)(i): an exit from the operational design domain of the ADS; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(17)(b)(ii): a system failure.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(18): "Level three automated driving system" or "level three ADS" means an ADS feature that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(18)(a): has the capability to perform on a sustained basis the entire dynamic driving task within its operational design domain; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(18)(b): requires a fallback-ready user to operate the vehicle after receiving a request to intervene or in response to a system failure.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(19): "Minimal risk condition" means a condition to which a user or an ADS may bring a motor vehicle in order to reduce the risk of a crash when a given trip cannot or should not be completed.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(20): "Object and event detection and response" means the subtasks of the dynamic driving task that include:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(20)(a): monitoring the driving environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(20)(b): executing an appropriate response in order to perform the dynamic driving task.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(21): "On-demand autonomous vehicle network" means a transportation service network that uses a software application or other digital means to dispatch or otherwise enable the prearrangement of transportation with motor vehicles that have a level four or five ADS in driverless operation for purposes of transporting persons, including for-hire transportation and transportation for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(22): 41-1a-102 "Operate" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(23): "Operational design domain" means the operating conditions under which a given ADS or feature thereof is specifically designed to function, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(23)(a): speed range, environmental, geographical, and time-of-day restrictions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(23)(b): the requisite presence or absence of certain traffic or roadway characteristics.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(24): 41-6a-102 "Operator" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(25): "Passenger" means a user on board a vehicle who has no role in the operation of that vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(26): 41-6a-102 "Person" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(27): "Remote driver" means a human driver with a valid driver license who is not located in a position to manually exercise in-vehicle braking, accelerating, steering, or transmission gear selection input devices, but operates the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(28): "Request to intervene" means the notification by an ADS to a fallback-ready user indicating that the fallback-ready user should promptly begin or resume operation of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(29): "Sustained operation of a motor vehicle" means the performance of part or all of the dynamic driving task both between and across external events, including response to external events and continued performance of part or all of the dynamic driving task in the absence of external events.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(30): "System failure" means a malfunction in a driving automation system or other vehicle system that prevents the ADS from reliably performing the portion of the dynamic driving task on a sustained basis, including the complete dynamic driving task, that the ADS would otherwise perform.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(31): "User" means a:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(31)(a): human driver;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(31)(b): passenger;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(31)(c): fallback-ready user; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-102.1(31)(d): driverless operation dispatcher.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103 Operation of motor vehicles equipped with an automated driving system.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1): 41-26-107 A motor vehicle equipped with a level three ADS may operate on a highway in this state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1)(a): the motor vehicle is operated, whether by the ADS or human driver with a valid driver license, in compliance with the applicable traffic and motor vehicle safety laws and regulations of this state, unless an exemption has been granted;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1)(b): when required by federal law, the motor vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1)(b)(i): has been certified as being in compliance with all applicable motor vehicle safety standards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1)(b)(ii): bears the required certification label, including reference to any exemption granted under federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1)(c): when operated by an ADS, if a system failure occurs that renders the ADS unable to perform the entire dynamic driving task relevant to the intended operational design domain of the ADS, the ADS will achieve a minimal risk condition or make a request to intervene; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(1)(d): 41-26-107 the motor vehicle is titled and registered in compliance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2): 41-26-107 A motor vehicle equipped with a level four or level five ADS may operate in driverless operation on a highway in this state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2)(a): the ADS is capable of operating in compliance with applicable traffic and motor vehicle laws and regulations of this state, unless an exemption has been granted;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2)(b): when required by federal law, the motor vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2)(b)(i): has been certified as being in compliance with all applicable Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards and regulations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2)(b)(ii): bears the required certification label including reference to any exemption granted under federal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2)(c): a system failure occurs that renders the ADS unable to perform the entire dynamic driving task relevant to the intended operational design domain of the ADS, a minimal risk condition will be achieved; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(2)(d): 41-26-107 the motor vehicle is titled and registered in compliance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(3): A vehicle being operated by an ADS or a remote driver is not considered unattended.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(4): The division may revoke the registration and privilege for a vehicle equipped with an ADS to operate on a highway of the state if the Department of Transportation or the Department of Public Safety determines and notifies the division that:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(4)(a): the ADS is operating in an unsafe manner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(4)(b): the vehicle's ADS is being engaged in an unsafe manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(5): 41-1a-102 Special mobile equipment, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-103(6): Nothing in this chapter prohibits or restricts a human driver with a valid driver license from operating a vehicle equipped with an ADS and equipped with controls that allow for the human driver to perform all or part of the dynamic driving task.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104 Licensing -- Responsibility for compliant operation of ADS-equipped vehicles.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
For the purpose of assessing compliance with applicable traffic or motor vehicle laws:Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(1)(a): When an ADS is operating a motor vehicle, the ADS is the operator, and shall satisfy electronically all physical acts required by a conventional driver in operation of the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(1)(b): The ADS is responsible for the compliant operation of the vehicle and is not required to be licensed to operate the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(2)(a): If a vehicle with an engaged level three ADS issues a request to intervene, the ADS is responsible for the compliant operation of the vehicle until disengagement of the ADS.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(2)(b): If a vehicle with an engaged level four or five ADS issues a request to intervene, the ADS is responsible for the compliant operation of the vehicle until or unless a human user begins to operate the vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-104(3): The ADS is responsible for compliant operation of an ADS-dedicated vehicle.


Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105 Duties following crashes involving motor vehicles equipped with an automated driving system.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(1): 41-6a-401; 41-26-103; Chapter 6a, Part 4, Accident Responsibilities In the event of a crash involving a vehicle with the ADS engaged:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(1)(a): 41-6a-401; 41-26-103 the ADS-equipped vehicle shall remain on the scene of the crash when required to do so under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(1)(b): Chapter 6a, Part 4, Accident Responsibilities the owner of the ADS-equipped vehicle, or a person on behalf of the vehicle owner, shall report any crashes or collisions consistent with
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(2): If the owner or person on behalf of the owner is not on board the vehicle at the time of the crash, the owner shall ensure that the following information is immediately communicated or made available to the persons involved or to a peace officer upon request:
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(2)(a): the contents of the vehicle's registration card; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(2)(b): the name of the insurance provider for the vehicle, including the phone number of the agent or provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(3): 41-6a-402 The department may require that an accident report filed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(3)(a): whether a vehicle equipped with an ADS was involved in the accident; and
Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-105(3)(b): whether the ADS was engaged at the time of the accident.

Utah Code Annotated § 41-26-108 Controlling authority.
------------------------------------------------------
No local agency, political subdivision, or other entity may prohibit the operation of a vehicle equipped with a driving automation system, an ADS, or an on-demand autonomous vehicle network, or otherwise enact or keep in force a rule or ordinance that would impose a tax, fee, performance standard, or other requirement specific to the operation of a vehicle equipped with a driving automation system, an ADS, or an on-demand autonomous vehicle network in addition to the requirements of this title.
